editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

div.p: The knave in grain, new vampt. A witty comedy, acted at the fortune many days together with great applause. Written by J. D. gent.
London: printed by J. O. and are to be sold by John Nicholson at his shop under st. Martin's church near Ludgate. 1640.

div.head: To the generous reader.
div.p: Courteous reader, the ancient Latin adage is, sultorum, but I say nebulonum plena sunt omnia, knaves be about all persons, and in all places. There are twelve coat-cards in the bunch, of which four are knaves, heart, diamond, spade, club, suiting with the four c c c c: court, city, country, camp: my purpose is not to touch any in particular; only thus much of them in general: some are notable, some notorious, some pimping, some panderly knaves; some prating, some pestilent; some cozening, some coney-catching knaves. There are also lazy and lying, base, and deboist, fantastical, foolish, and false knaves. To these we may add heretical and hypocritical, schismatical, and separistical knaves: not forgetting perjured, and shameless; impudent, and informing; arrogant, and arrant knaves, cum multis alijs. And besides these, I have heard of a knave tapster, a knave ostler, a knave sergeant, and a knave broker: but with these we have nothing to do at this time; only with a knave in grain, or a knave new vampt, in deciphering of whom, I give all the rest this caveat, have amongst you my masters: and now if any of the rest shall find himself touched, he hath his mends in his own hands, for he cannot say but I gave him fair warning. And so much of the argument, the act follows.

list.item: A rabble of boys and others.

body.head: The knave in grain; or new vampt.

div.head: Actus primus. Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Why how now puss, what ails my monkey to chatter out of tune thus?

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: A whoreson senseless coxcomb — but I am glad thou'rt come, I long for a pottle of wine and a capon.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Good provision for the present monkey, but viderit futuritas, in the mean time, who lays up for futurity? Come you raise four hundred per annum, out of pottles of wine and capons?

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: Yes my Granado, in this quality: they that come short of my breeding have don't. The first credit I won was in a garrison.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: In holland.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: No; and yet in the low countries: I never sat foot in a leaguer yet.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The reason of that?

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: My hard fate nothing else, having as much impudence, and as many ways to manage it, receiving weekly corantoes from Paris, Rotterdam, and flushing, and having trade too in Middleborough, I have been house lecturer three years together, and read Aretine, both in print and picture, and that is much for one of my years.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: 'T may be thou wantest acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: No such matter, the old exchange, the new burse, and new town, afford plenty; not a prentice that can cry bawd, nor a butcher's dog that can say bow wow, but is of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Yet it may be they are precise, and will not be seen in't.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: That I know not, but most sure, I have feasted the liberty twice at mine own charge, and helped their wives and daughters to the earning of many a fair pound: they will be seen in that.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Well, I am sure I have furnished thy library with all books of behaviour, and tables of entertainment.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: And I have culled out all my phrases as curiously and stuck my language with such enticing conveniences: and for intelligence, all the lawn women, lace women, box women, and to come nearer to the business, very hair women, periwig women, and candied elicumpany lick halberds, come in twice a week like decoy ducks, with whole shoals at the tail of them.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Why, then there's a fault in your company.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: Ay, ay, that villainous company undoes all, there's Lodowick Tomaso Valentine, high talkers, and deep drinkers, but they have wit in their wine, and too much honesty in their actions at all time, there's only on gentleman —

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Stultissimo of a plain cut and square size, he runs just as you throw him; rub him a little against the grain now, and he will come off a great deal the smoother. You would not think, what charitable benefactors three or four such plush colonels would be to the founding of a new honour.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: But hast thou such a purpose, indeed?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Why should not I have purpose and effect as much as any: a leager, yes, so it lay in the I'll of plenty; I'd dig through the Alps with Hannibal, and fetch Theseus from hell, with Hercules' purpose and practice, my precious monkey, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: And shall I come to the honour to write mistress of the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Shall not bate an accent of that title my catamptiall monkey, but you must look out for spider's monkey, and the Sprall of all four puzz: I have laid the foundation in gold already.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: Hast had a good return of thy ring's chuck?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Rings hangum, they are as stale as Scotch Lanson, or as your Decoy,
No, I have sent 'em out in a desperate venture to cape.
No monkey, my old friend Franciscus hath repaired my jacket already, and has promised to new thatch my outside too.
One of these boxes has 100 pieces of new gold,
With chains and keys correspondent.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: For what use chick?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: For a dead lift monkey: a leaguer cannot be planted, manned, victualled and munitioned with a small magazine: to work monkey, a mouzing puss, make choice of your company, admit no parley with the popular, be high and proud of thyself, and let those that will needs buy thee, pay soundly for thee with a pox to 'em, puss a wink to the wise, you know my mind, let's have no more midnight catterwowlings under sale-mens shop windows, vintners dark cellars, no justices long entries, but bear up yourself so civil and so meager ▪
You may be styled a sister of the leaguer.

div.stage: Enter Dulciflora a whore, and mistress durable a bawd, old signior Stultissimo a foolish gentleman, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Away you rogue.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman body and soul I'll break your windows.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Master, as you are a man stand and tickle her.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will you, you rascal.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Ah, sweet heart, prithee good woman.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Nay, let her come I'll give her heart belly full.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Let her alone Fub: let her alone, by this hand, I'll make the boys maul her ruffs.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Fie how I am tired a whoreson stinking shamelegged, fie, fie, fie, use a gentlewoman thus in her own lodging.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: How does your back, oh the fucas, out alas, here's half a crown in complexion utterly cast away.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: If I be not even with the rutter —

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: If he come where you have to do, let him pay soundly.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: A plague upon his ass's ears, by my virginity, I'll send his beard into newfoundland for this.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: And so I would, to make lines to catch cods: out, out, out, a gentleman, and use a woman no otherwise; i'faith, yfath, it stands not with his reputation.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: A whoreson smelled: mistress durable, I would I had some of your aqua vitae, I'm sick after the conflict.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: And shall good woman, come, come, pray keep yourself warm.

div.stage: Enter Franciscus, and Julio, Julio very poor.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Forsake me honour, when I do forget the bond of friendship, let not poverty, no, nor your father's behaviour Julio: though our Venetian law proved him a traitor: come
pluck away your interest from my breast: when we were pupils in the academy, I was Franciscus and your fellow then; I am Franciscus and your fellow still, nor can be altered: I have now a heart as free from pride, as when I clipped thee thus, before thou knew'st the taste of poverty, or I prosperity. Think not ancient friend I can forget thee, though thy need were such as beggary despised.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The liberal hand of heaven reward your love, or lend my wishes that ability to thank you in requital.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Amen to that and more.

I tell thee Julio, I am not happier in my virtuous wife: and yet that's greater than yielding thee relief 'tis all that good men wish: why have we wealth bestowed on us, but to return the same, where stern necessity pinches the ribs of him or her that wants? it has no other worth, no more esteem of me. Heap it together while the, massy weight e'en crack, what bears it less than dust? on dust deserves no more regard. I have a wife, nurse, and mother, all she is in one; yet one deserves more titles, besides her feature, which may make compare with those that boast of parts: she is so kind, that many millions may be stamped again, ere one so perfect currant. She is worth more than the earth is: but she is my wife, and I will cease her praise: you know her father when you have his name: he is called Chrysippus, many style him good, and wish all Venice such.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Ere I was banished for my father's fact, my knowledge coated, and all Italy, spoke of a damosel called Cornelia, this good chrysippus daughter.

div.stage: Enter Chrisippus, Cornelia, Anthonio, Tomaso, Phemono, Stultissimo, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She is that jewel, that unmatched, thing I made my boast of: that Cornelia is none but mine, I dare boldly say, and eke affirm it: see my julio, she meets us unexpected, and comes to hinder what I would speak more, in cause of her demerit, modesty, and sweetness.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Franciscus: son!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My love and duty make me ever such.
To all this company a happy hour.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You have been missed Franciscus.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You have been missed Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Where ere I have been, this is my friend, tender him your welcome with as good respects as I myself where he.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Sir, bid your own welcome, and command as much as all we have, were yours.

sp.speaker: Julio
sp.p: Your courtesies to one so thronged in misery as myself, dulls my behaviour, that I know not how enough to laud or thank you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You shall exchange your habit:
Phemone, sister, Anthonio —

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: We missed you yesternight .

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I durst not come believe it:
Vallentius for says rouses are too great,
They make me quake to see 'em.
How fares my cousin Lodwick?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: He spoilt our sport: he was not well he said:
I would you had been there: Tomaso pledged you twice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I thank his love.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: It is not worth it sir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I'faith nephew I was extreme drunk, ask my man Fub else, he'll tell you what a coil he had with me: the rarest jest i'faith: prithee tell 'em how thou foundst me underneath the stairs.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: By no means, 'twill make 'em drunk to hear it.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Signior Arbaces you are the man I wished for.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Well met gentlemen: are you here Antonio?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: No, 'tis no matter. Tomaso you shall do't,
Go see nothing want; you are all my guests, you dine with
Me that's certain: nay, I will not be denied:
Most welcome sir to you: will you walk?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ever, ever welcome.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Will you walk sir? will you munch?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Sirrah Fub, thou wouldst not think how sore my head is, ever since I had the knock with the ladle?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I believe you: will you feed sir?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: No more i'th' ladle. Methinks I am pocky melancholy here of late.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: So I guessed, ever since you knew the gentlewoman that beat you.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Thou sayest true, ever since i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Why she is able to make anybody pocky melancholy. But would you would snap a bit sir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I love her I cannot tell how: i'faith and I were well searched, I think I am little kin to a spaniel, the more I am beaten, the better I affect.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Would I were sure of that.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Well, she shall hear from me in some sonnet or ditty; some rare thing of mine own invention, and that speedily: let me see to what tune shall I have it?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: And if you please, let it go to the punks delight; 'tis your only sweet tune: for women do love the punks delight.

sp.speaker: Stultis.
sp.p: By this hand gramercy; they do indeed, thou canst sing if need be.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I can make a scurvy shift: but to say truth I am no good chorister.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: But canst thou do well and scurvily?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: After my manner.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Would I might be hanged presently, but methinks I am a piece of a poet already, there's such a whistling in my pate.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: That's nothing but your conceit sir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Conceit merrily: oh that my love were any thing but woman.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: O that your love were any thing but common: then might she be. —

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.p: What might she be.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Nay what you will i'faith.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.p: I'll to't while 'tis hot, I know I'm in an excellent vein.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Prick it quickly then:
But hark you signior, shall you not need my help?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I defy't, it shall be all mine own, I cannot abide, 'tis the scurviest thing to rob others of their wit, good or bad, it shall flow from mine own sweet brain.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I believe you'll find the tide turned, 'tis ebbing water there, would I might be begged, as he had like to have been, if his foolery do not vex my discretion, but he gives me means, and I could do little if I could not smile.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well Vallentius, and you be caught ith' purlieus: and you be not stung for't I'll forswear privacy, and all that belongs too●●, I have a girl, the very spirit of what she was made for, and she were honest, she might crave supremacy of Helen, and make her ride behind.

sp.speaker: Vallen.
sp.p: And I love one were she not honest, that's her only fault, she were a paragon unparallelled, mingle all beauty that our Venice yields, and set herself aside, she would stand peerless, overshine them all, and dim the artists cunning.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is she a woman?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Yes, but such a one no voluntary habit, nor sly drift with all accommodations that beseems, unblemished truth itself can bring to speech or give my thoughts access.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What is she for a saint, that stands in the how fair and beautiful: may one of my birth entreat her name and knowledge?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Vow your assistance to my purposes, and I a traitor to myself reveal the treason of my mind.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Give me your hand, I am yours for better or worse, in all causes, all adventures, my sword and self vow fealty: is she a wife?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Ay, would she were not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Know you Vanderman our great physician.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
What, my fretful doctor? the only curer of mad folks;
know I myself?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You know he's married.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, and what of this (O would you be ministering therein.) I have you my dear Flora, well take my word she's thine.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: I would that I were hers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why it lies in thine own choice.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: But setting all this pleasantness aside, in earnest Lodowick I affect her so, no motive mean nor yet dire accident can change my steadfast will, I must enjoy her, or I must not live.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou shalt enjoy her, or I will not live.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You speak like a friend.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I speak like what I am, a christian, and by that epithet, I meant as much as I speak, nor could I think, Vallentius, you of all the men alive, would have mistaken me.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: In any kind but this I never had: pardon me Lodowick this doting loves bears such a jealous sway, the least suspicion puts us on the wrack, and breaks all chains of duty: you may persuade me to believe, but yet he that never saw a vessel under sail, cannot imagine what the seaman brooks, the merchant sleeping on his downy couch, never dreams what danger the bold soldier dures, and he that never felt the pangs of hell, cannot report the torments: assure thee Lodowick so be satisfied, since I knew her, I have not known myself, so mighty is love's extremes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis strange.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: She troth plight was to me, and had been mine, had not desire of pelf altered her friends, and I dare well vow she loved me once, whate'er her mind be now.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come be ruled by me, thou shalt set thy toe in the doctor's stirrup, ride and go a foot at thy pleasure: did she love thee once?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: I had her oath.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Go to, renew thy suit, the fire is not all out, stir up
the ashes, and thou dost not find some embers, that will both glow and warm, pawn me for buttered sack, and let me never be worthy redemption.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I want the means.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Think not of that, 'tis here my Flora, what man? he's not the first doctor has worn a corner cap: come, will you be merry Vallentius, and you'll forsake not this mood, I renounce society.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am yours, obedient as your hand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Follow me then, and I drive not this melancholy fit out of thee, I'll never trust my conceit: what, ho damazella? Knocks, and Clarislona looks out at the window.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He's here that should be here, come down?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What's she.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The commodity I told you of, there's a gentleman a friend of yours in love with her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not yourself.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No faith, though you shall hear her swear as much, 'tis our rich heir signior Stultissimo.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What, the fool?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That morsel of man's flesh, she cannot beat him away, he haunts the Eves like a sparrow in march, you may hunt flies from honey sooner then him out of her company: now mistress how stands things with you, when did you play with your fool's babble?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: You'll never leave this.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Bid my friend welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I thank you lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come kiss me?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will you stay all night?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, when I am weary of strength, and foes with my back.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: I'faith Lodowick, you must leave this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So I will ▪

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: When thou leavest thy trade?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will you sup here?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes drink, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Lord, how wise your grown?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So I were, if I could keep out of your company.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Fie, you're to uncourteous Lodwick: nay, he's ever thus, but 'tis my fault.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry mend it then for shame.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Where's my bracelet, which of your trulls has that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Shall I be true to thee?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: You're never true to me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I mean honest.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: I care not for your honesty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I believe that too, but in plain verity. Your bracelet embraces my horses main.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Come, you jest.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No good troth.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Swear you, I hope you make a difference between your horse and me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Faith but little: and yet you're both good bearers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By the bright sun you wrong her: weep not fair one.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, shall we have tricks?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are too blame beshrew me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Now, when, what needs all this, nay, and you pout farewell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman you part not so.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Sweet, Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hum, why was not this before, I have seen the bears.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Do not I know your woman?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Hist, hist, are you the man of war?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, you must draw nearer, if you'll have your embassy answered: how is't mistress durable?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: How do you master Lodowick?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The worse for you, and your creatures.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: It's a good hearing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Shall I have three or four words in private?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Not with her unless I participate.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Yonder's Fub, the party's man you wot on has something under hand and seal.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: For me.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: So he gives out.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: You may admit him.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Rest you merry gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who's this secret party, this concealed champion ▪ what have ye here, signior Stultissimo's man?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: All hail.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: This fellow would keep a vild coil if he were a top ath' tiles.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Gentiles, good speed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, the plough?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: No, you, and you please, Marona to yourself.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This fellows discreet.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: So says his backside.

sp.speaker: Julio
sp.p: You the man of war, or more properly pirate, that gave summons to the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Leaguer, sir.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Leaguer, sir, the report of your potguns cannot make us hang up a white flag.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: The skirt of a clean smock's more proper ath' two.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: We come not to learn what's proper of you, monkey, and catch flies.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Play at his foolery, come hither punk.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Sir, you're uncivil, she's none; nor this a bawdy house; but a leaguer of gentle entertainment.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The fellow dreams: come wake and be thyself.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Myself? Would you were as sure yourselves as I am.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'd fain know that of you:
But I advise you to take council of your best judgement first,
Your words will be questioned.

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.p: Question that dares, thou'rt an arrant cheater.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: 'Tis not your pair royal of plush coxcombs can secure you in't.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: Valiant a the sudden too.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Not suddenly neither:
The growth has both time and sufficient temper.
Why I a cheater? let any impartial —
Ride circuit, and sit in judgement of us all,
And show any reason either in art or nature,
Why I a cheater more than any of you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou hast nothing but a little wit to live upon.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: That's endowment enough for a gentleman:
I ever shall count him the nobler gentleman
That makes himself a fortune in the world, than he
That brings it into the world with him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Suppose this granted: yet why this a leaguer?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I want words for you: only for conclusion, one out of a strange affected carriage has gathered an admirable method of drilling, and training men from the flying of cranes: another rare order and government of commonwealths, from the poor labour of the bee: and I out of this leaguer —

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: Will extract certain ways and carriages for cheaters and libertines.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
'Twere not from my purpose if I granted that to. Lycurgus was the first lawmaker; and the best law that ever he made, was a provision or maintenance for cheats, as you call 'em, and felons (Viz.) That he (Without exception of
age, quality, or condition) which could do the most high dainty, and dangerous piece of felony, and come clear off, should be preferred to the most eminent place of office in the state; but if he failed, he was then to receive martial law.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: Strange course, pick officers out of felons.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: 'Tis a kind of meslin or mingled grain still. How much of the poors money was found in one of the churchwardens purchase last day?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: None I think.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: How many thieves horses have been watered at the high constable of the hundreds watering trough within this ten years?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I think not any.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: It may be so: but I am sure, I have heard, or read ▪ or something, that a new chief justice of some place, or a better man would not ha' made very nice to bid a fat purse to breakfast with him if he light upon it soundly: so that it is not so much the art to know, as the government to dispose: that qualifies the man.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: He says true: all times ha' been guilty of good fellowship, why not this? I like the leaguer now so well, I care not if I buy a place of command in it myself.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Why now you come to me,
That's the pearl I ha' dived for all this while:
I have a catalogue of names, places, and prizes.
A cup of entertainment for my friend.
Welcome to the new leaguer.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: We'll pledge, we'll pledge:
Victualled and wined already?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: To the society at the swan two pottles and a half: monkey the health; these are my noble and prime visitants ; the boxes I gave you to lay up.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now Julio, gold?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: By this light, and the most curious.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
A poor granam's gift gentlemen: 300 pieces, or such a taste, partly induction to a business, or so. There's a
Bordeaux merchant in town now, would lay me between wind and water this twelvemonth , but the spite is, I am tied not to part with this gold for ever: if I knew where to borrow but half the worth on't —

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: Half the worth?
I'll vow to lend the full worth,
If that will pleasure thee.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: You shall keep the gold under lock and key for your pawn.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou shalt not want for such a courtesy to do thee good: I'm glad thou'rt so thriving.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Lock up the box, and keep the key; there's the full sum.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: To a piece I assure you: you shall see else again.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No more, no more trouble:
Let me see for how long?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Three months, not a day longer:
Nay sooner if money chance to come in afore:
I have offices in my leaguer stand upon fortune's hill.
'Uds me signior Stultissimo promised
Me a courtesy last night:

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Assure thee sweet chuck he'll not fail thee.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: I believe thee without an oath:
Make my friend welcome to the leaguer monkey:
As soon as I have dispatched my voyage
To the canaries, I am for you again lads.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.p: Gentlemen, who can read?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who cannot?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I can resolve you:
She cannot.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's here?
Opprobrious saint, and most angelic fiend,
Ere I begin, thus do I make an end.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I should have been sorry else:
Nay silence, or the proclamation's lost.
And if thy heart be not patched up in marble,
Hark how my pen does in thy praises warble.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O dear Apollo, how art thou abused, is there more?

lg.l: Sweet stinging wasp, and well conceited dove ▪
For beauty nice, entitled Queen of love
Of me; sir reverence; that does thee adore;
Which art esteemed a good one and no more:
Let reason rule thy Amazonian fist ▪
Let ladle rude be thrown at hady wist,
So shall I love thee, take it for no fable
Better than well, and more than I am able.

closer.signed: Yours despite your guts. S. s.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ass, ass.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The authors name.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Cannot you get her signior Stultissimo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O, lamentable complaint!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: As ever poor man heard.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will he take no warning.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is this a challenge?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Fie no, they are too violent to come in rhyme.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Lodowick, is not this your practice?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why, dost thou think me so simple, so ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: No, I'll assure you, it's a token of good will of my masters, there's no brain guilty on't but his own: if you like it you may, and you will not, the laws in your own hands, you may choose.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Good gentlemen return the carrier.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What? A cuff or a knock.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: He has penned a song too, which I should have tickled, if I had not been hoarse with drinking flapdragons last night.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Fub.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Prithee honest Fub, tickle thyself out of our companies, we'll be fubbed no longer.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Will not you be fubbed sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou knowest my resolution.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Nay, but will ye not indeed?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No faith ▪

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I am glad I know't, — be with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Have you any wine ith' house?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Yes dearest.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come, a pox a these devices, hang off: will you drink Vallentius?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will I live?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Where's the matron?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: The matron, lord, you're the strangest man. —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your matron grandum, what will you have it, your bawd?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: I must be quiet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, enter, enter.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The easy time, and such as thrive in it, favour my wishes, the ignorant whose sole dependence is on verity, and carry conscience in their timorous breasts, are not associates meet for Julio. Those that ne'er knew the strain of policy, nor aim at more, then what may well content, draw not my length, the way to prosper, the directest course such are my sore necessities, is to get liking of this lovely maid Franciscus' sister, bright Phemone, the virgin's modest, chaste, and debonair, besides her brother's rich, there hang my hopes, but she affects not me, all her desires are on young Antonio's, rich Arbaces son, my friend (Supposed) at least, but that is breath; by what man has, or can have, he's my foe that hinders my design, where he my next of blood, that shall he find: the mean to purchase what I reach at now, there is but only one, one only means that can supplant him, here it lies shall do't, were he as dear in estimation as Nisus to Euryalus.
sp.l: I love myself, I count him still most wise,
That cares not who's thrown down so he arise.

div.head: Actus secundus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Franciscus and Julio. sound music.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thou hast to say something, yet nothing I hope trivial, by our known affection I beseech thee, speak what thou canst.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I would I had embraced my poverty, while the pale moon has residence in heaven, would I had been deaf.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Whereto tends this speech if I thought my fault, or any ones pertained to me, through wilful negligence, or otherwise, to breed the occasion of this passionate mood, I should condemn the cause of the offence, and deem myself unhappy.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Can heaven suffer it?

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.p: What, what does heaven suffer, speak my Julio?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Too much of ill.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me know that ill, and I rest satisfied.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Pray no more, the malady is mortal, unsanctified, monstrous. Anthonio is there such a man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Many that wear that name in Italy: but one amongst that many known to me.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Hate all the name.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pardon Julio, I'll hate myself first.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Anthonio is a villain.

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.p:
Blot not the reputation of his youth with such
calumny, he is no way such, but as unblemished, as the snow before it touch the mountains.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He's a villain.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Villain never had so fair an outside, nor yet heart so just as that he carries.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He's a villain.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have some business at the port, you'll sup with me tonight .

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Do you love yourself, do you love honour, do you love your wife?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Then hate that Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Give me to understand, since you will force me to endure your report, wherein he's culpable, or does deserve these ignominious titles.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He loves not you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis not my fault.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He wrongs your sister.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Therein, he's too blame.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He loves your wife.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That amends, quits all his former wrongs.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Can you bear it thus, wink Vulcan then,
And let the god of war, throw up her skirts again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: You will not understand; I'll speak no further.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come, come, my wife is honest.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If she be, 'tis nothing you have said, I'll hear no more; begone.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Will you list a word, Anthonio wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wrong me, and if he would he cannot.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He plays the parasite, the officious ass to veil his sin.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Would I might understand you?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The serpent tempts your wife, these ears and eyes can testify; for your sister, she's stale: his excuse, whereby he cloakes his vice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I wish you Julio, to know what you speak.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I am not mad, I love you, 'tis my love, you are my father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I pray be advised, consider what you do? speak not this no report, be certain; do not abuse my patience. Tempt my wife, rent earth, and swallow falsehood.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Will you be moved Parnassus, the two topped, forked mount?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My blood is not mine own, I want command of all that now obeyed me, how different are my fits? I am now a congealed, kneaded cake of ice, bound from all motion, now again ( methinks ) a flaming island, a Vesuvius hill, merely combustion.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Forget not, sir, your patience.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Tell me of patience when I am myself: how did he tempt her, how did she accord on thy reputation?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I would I had been dumb?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hang not ith' wind, (Delay does torture) answer me as how?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Kind, sir, recall your wonted manhood?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Answer me how.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I pray pardon me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What? strike and cry mercy, I must be resolved, thou hast flung me ith' fire, even in the oven, the mouth of Aetna, nothing thou couldst have said, nothing have done, could have assured like torture.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Would, when I saw him kiss her, crush her hand, wink and laugh out, use his undecent language: fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cornelia false, the flood may come again, nothing impossible, kiss, and crush hands, wink, wink heaven and all above.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Kind, sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bear witness, all that good are, how dear, how dear, I held that most false man: set him here, here, even on the spire and pinnacle of my heart; my life was his, and all that I call mine, but her he has abused?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p:
Dear friend, do not forget your name, these are but likelihoods, far from the thing itself, and say he be a villain,
as no doubt he's little better in his rude exposures: she may be honest.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No Julio, no, had she meant well,
She would have warned me of his foul attempts,
Said such, and so's his behaviour.
When she was loyal, as sure one she was,
(If ever any was) no accident how vain
So e'er it seemed, but she a woman, would unfold
Her sex, and say 'twas thus, and thus.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I have struck him through.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Treble abuse:
Deflowered my wife, abused me,
Disgraced my sister; thrown infamy
On all our heads at once: what beast uncivil bred,
Amongst careless monsters (But thee Antonio)
Would have been kicked on to that damned enterprise?
That I had patience; methinks thou shouldst not
Be the villain yet, report does speak thee.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Nay gentle friend.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis true, 'tis true.
Had any 'twixt the North and Southern pole
Spoke these words but he, it had not been,
And he had falsely lied.
This is a creature I have raised, revived,
Snatched from destruction's teeth,
Incorporated to me, so dear and just, as not
A thing in all the world can be more truer to itself
And certain: but his modesty conceals it,
Could write a volume of their loathed designs,
And curse the storeys cause. O false Cornelia!

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Remember what you are.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Remembrance burst!
There's no contemplation, nothing whate'er can
Drive the thought of shame out of my mind:
Would I had never known discretion,
Could never have made distinctions of persons,
And harmless creatures; hence forth be ignorance:
mother of nations and understanding perish:
Fair, foul Cornelia. The blue faced
Ocean, nor her fertile womb, that yields
Us all increase, nourishes none so false as woman:
Traitors have they been since their first being,
And betrayed poor man ere he beheld himself.
Cornelia can it be thou art a strumpet?
O, o, fury finish that, burns thee to cinders.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Work on, work on:
Fate lifts me to the seat of my desires;
And I am prosperous and happy.
This devil jealousy, my present friend,
Cannot at least but quite supplant Anthonio:
Besides this seeming honesty of mine, begets me good
Opinion of Franscicus, as shall install my wish;
All adds to my avail: what need I curses fear
For the debate my policy shall raise betwixt these turtles ▪
I hold with Machiavel, for fame or profit
To break oath or league with friend,
Or brother: there's nothing gainful bad:
I ha' my wish, advancement now
Is what I aim at, present glory here:
He's true religious, that does nothing fear.

div.stage: Enter Thomaso, Valentius, Lodwicks, Stultissimo, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: And how? and how?
Was it not pathetical and pretty?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'faith I never heard the like.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I thank the Muses, I have as sharp a conceit of mine own when I list.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir I take you to be a great devourer of verjuice.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Now and then; but 'tis not altogether that; every one has his gift.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis so.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Some has two or three.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You say true signior, some has twenty: for which they may thank impudence and the art of begging.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: The art of begging: pray you how long has begging been an art?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ever since in rid in a footcloth, and wore the badge of authority.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: How long's that ago?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ever since you granam's daughter had a calf of your age.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, and will continue till he's a bull and horn mad.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Most miraculous: would I were mercenary, and had no more in me than an ordinary man: signior, I cry you mercy. How do you since you poured the pottle of wine in my neck, and threw the pot at my head, because I would not pay my part o'th shot?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Was there such a time?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Was there? Why have you forgotten how you kicked me, and I crept under the table: I'll be sworn this hip's as lame ever since, as if I had the cyatica.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Absurd and gross.

sp.speaker: Vallen.
sp.p: We must leave you signior.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: I thank you with all my heart: I am going to the foresaid place: here's my servant Fub can tell you if I lie in my throat.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I will assure you he's wandering to Puss, or as a man would say, to deal with mistress Clariflora.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Yes faith am I: she beat me tother day, and I am now going to make her amends. I think I endure more beating than any three in Venice.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Than a stockfish.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign you are offensive.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: So they say that do't. Yesternight a scurvy boy did so jowl my head and the wall together, for holding opinion that cheese was unwholesome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No more good signior: farewell.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: At your service:
Shall we expect you at the old house?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you please:
Have you heard the like?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: These are asses so tedious —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They're kin to burrs, they will not off with shaking.
Now my Thomaso what I have to say:
The chief occasion made me summon you,
Is to entreat your knowledge and assistance
In such a project, (As yourself set by) and him that must
Partake in the attempt, Venice in Italy
Conceals the man that I durst credit.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Let it not touch confusion of the state,
Treason, and murder: whatsoever it be,
Command my will and sufferance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Defend that ever I should be such:
Vallentius never had so foul a thought,
To infect himself, and others.
Thus, in brief, I love a woman; fairer
Than herself never wore the epithet:
You have seen her sure, and know her:
She's wife to Vanderman.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Correma's daughter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That same only wight, is the most precious
Beauty I adore, and would fain call mine own.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Knew you her husband?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By his name, no further;
By that knowledge you understand his course.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Yes he's a physician: and besides,
What else report speaks of him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Listen then my purpose,
The severe sir, whose high stretched phrases
Galls the ears of patience, and wisdom would fain shun,
Bears such a jealous and observant eye
Over the prey I aim at, all conference is debarred,
And you may sooner whisper with the saint
Argos had charge of, than converse with her,
unseen, and unsuspected.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Is there no device to compass her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But one, and this is it;
Yourself and Lodwick (Harken I beseech you)
Shall to this skilful Vanderman present me
As one distracted: nay smile anon,
And with a kind of sober modesty, as if you list you can,
Report some probable possibility, how
And which way I got my ecstasy:
Let me alone to make your words seem truth,
And so possess my prating mountebank,
That he shall say and swear I'm mad at least.
If not passed all recovery.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Will this do?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This, or none.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Then none.
Why this is the shallowest, indirectest course to win a woman that ever was composed, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In your opinion: why sir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why, hope you to gain her thus with a mad fit: mark the event, this is a course as wide: are you so simple to imagine, she a timorous woman, will endure your presence, seeming possessed? for shame believe it not, invent some other means.

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: I verily think so too, but he will never be persuaded.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This were a way to scare her, and to make her shun you.

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: Leav't off, leave't off, and study some other new passage.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Do, do; this is the grossest: fie Vallentius:

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: Come, you shall pardon him once: we all miss sometimes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Good gallants do not ride me, lest I gall you: I'll assure you I trot hard: why my brace of conceits, my wits; what does your abundance of wit run at waste: for shame, have you so poor a brain, and you my most exquisite excellent,
for shame take off your spectacles and see better: are you such a dunce: are you so rare a coxcomb, to deem I will appear always the same: are you the men you promised? will you be masters of your words and oaths, tender your vowed assistances?

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: I am Lodwick still.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And I Tomaso.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Continue so: what shall redound upon this adventure, falls upon my head, be it no shame to yours: only preferment and your smooth apologies.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Leave that to us.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: But can you act the madman bravely?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tut, I have played Ajax, and performed the part well, to make boast of imitation, better than he that Lucian writes of, who so digested what he played, that he run mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Can you do't?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So well, as Aesop could discharge his scene, whereby he won most laud.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This praise were well in me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Mistrust not my behaviour, and if it prove not correspondent to my word, think me an idle vaunter, and no meet associate for you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: When put we this in practice?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There's no deferring weeks, nor days, this hour, this very evening does my fit begin.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Shall we about it then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What else, what else? Remember gentlemen you fall not upon the scandal of ignorance: but in any case keep your countenances.

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: Make no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come then, and fortune friend us.

div.stage: Enter Francisco, and Antonio, as in a grove.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Draw your sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Gainst whom?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Gainst me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Gainst any living man that's your enemy:
what ails my dear Francisco?
By your face you should not be in health.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Draw your sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Draw your sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Gainst you never in anger:
Are you well Franciscus? methinks your cheek
Carries a paler hue than wont to be his livery.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I must fight with you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: With thee perfidious monster, with thee thou Judas.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you yourself?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thou hast abused me, wronged me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wronged and abused you?
Franciscus, can you think so of me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do not inquire; yonder he sits knows all:
Look yonder, thou art to him transparent, and seen through,
As easy as the air: do not cloak thy vice, do not:
Seest thou this? seest thou the place we tread on?
Mark my speech, one of us twain, or both (Never start)
On this cold earth, this very champion, shall
Offer up a crimson sacrifice of his most precious blood:
For that cause drew I to this silent shade,
Remote from all suspicion, where
Revenge might glut with satisfaction:
Draw thy sword, or else thou never shalt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Did not my love prohibit,
Think, Francisco, I could not be a coward,
Nor endure the opprobrious taunts the malice
Of your heart has made your tongue throw on me;
Why I know not: believe me, and receive it for a truth,
Were you some other, in this wide vast world,
And not Franciscus, you had been a dog
That I had kicked long since; but you are my friend,
And my disgrace is buried: yet if you carry honour
In your breast, and bear your wonted venerable mind,
Make me to understand from whence, or why your
Comminations and undecent language point thus at me alone?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will you draw?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you thirst for blood? if so, and mine, hide to the hilts your naked instrument, my bosom is your mark: thrust home and take your fill.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will you draw?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You had mine answer, never ▪ never.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do you not love my wife?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Confess, o impudence! my wrong cries out, no more expostulation, remember Julio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wherefore him, he is a toad more virulent, o, o!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Bath there, adulterate fiend, and thy red drops wash off thy guilty stains.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, some charitable creature!
Francisco, dear Francisco.
No pity, no remorse, I bleed, and much effusion robs me of my breath, something of sense relieve me, help, o help.

sp.speaker: Shepherd
sp.p: That dying tune, was sure a man's, where art thou friend, speak thou that cried'st for help, if thou wouldst have thy wish, speak once again: where art thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Shepherd
sp.l: To one in thy case could I ne'er less wish, than health and mercy, how fare you sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Shepherd
sp.p: His utterance is decayed, and life begins to creep out of his wounds: let me see, so many, and so mortal! can I but stay the course I wish no more: have I nothing left, to stay this passage: well, yet still he breathes, that I had here some help. Thy aid omnipotent, yet his pulses beat, life is not quite discharged, — no succour! keep he but motion, till I can bear him to my cell, I doubt not, his recovery: this wind, this wind, that my balms were here: for my youthful day's heaven lend ability.

div.stage: Enter Crissippus, Tomaso, Lod wick, Julio, Cornelia, and Phemone.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Run to all brief confusion.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good, sir, be pacified.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Even in the pride, and noon time of his fortunes, brought to destruction thus: a milder, better tempered gentleman, Venice nor Europe yielded; his knowledge made me proud, and I was rich in his adoption.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: O my Franciscus, o my gentle lord!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: My brother, my dear brother.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: My son, my son, so noble, valiant, wise, dearer to me than him I call mine own by true succession, do you weep?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I am not blessed, all things do sort contrary; 'twill not do, my projects thrive not, would I had been silent, we know the first, but not the last, I begin to perceive our policies of times whets the axe, cuts off our own necks; I have and one myself, that it should come to this, we seek to mend so long, that we mar all: for mine own part, would I could have been content: but who would have dreamt the course would have proved so violent: well this I am sure on, I may starve ere I get such another friend.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sister, if it be true, as so the rumour goes, you have played false, and wronged your dearest friend: you are not worthy such another man, you sole Queen of Afrique; had you to live as many ample years as our first fathers, or their ages thrice: you might spend all those tedious houses twice told, ere you find a mate so worthy, were you equivalent, in birth and beauty, and had no parallel: Neptune's gems to boot, you want worth and excellency both, to weigh down his demerit; virtue and honour stamped him for their own, at his first being, and the graces strove to increase his plenitude. More perfection than he has, he needs not, where ere he's betook.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Something that's mighty, stain me leopard like, if ere I gave offence.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: I should be loath to wish so.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Not you offend? look here,
This letter left he as a testimony,
Who is there here 'mongst all this company,
That knew Franciscus, knew not he affected,
And highly prized the slain Antonio?
What could have raised such deadly enmity?
But this, but this, thou strumpet,
Between such twinlike friends?
Thy misdemeanour, thy approved falseness;
Which too, too well he knew ▪
Thou hast und one him,
Fled he is and gone;
His goods already seized are for the state:
And die he shall if ever he be taken,
O, fie upon thee my perpetual shame!

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Can you this behold, you upright justices?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Thou art not mine, I here deny thy claim,
And warn thee henceforth,
Come not near my roof:
Pine, starve and die, relief and comfort
Never more expect from him that was thy father.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing I see, to work the dissolution of a house,
How easily this is done?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I must weep, to deem
I should be forced to be so cruel;
More I have to say, if tears would let me;
( methinks ) I could both kiss and curse her:
If she be wronged, and through some make-strife,
These foul ills prove a greater plague,
Then fell in Egypt, light on the author's head,
The maws of dogs be his tomb:
Help me to curse him Julio.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Ten thousand swords struck me together.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Lived there such a wretch,
And that I knew him,
Let my faith not save me,
But I would tear the viper with my teeth,
And like a rude and savage cannibal,
Eat out his treacherous heart.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Now the foul devil, stuff thy gluttonous paunch,
I am no viand for thee?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who's this comes here, Arbaces?

div.stage: Enter Arbaces, with two or three gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Disgrace and woe smite all this company, and make them feel my grief.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Disgrace, contagion, and what can be worse,
Smite thee and all thy tribe.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Undone, undone, where is Anthonio?
Where's my son Crisippus?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Answer thine own words;
Where's mine Arbaces?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Where such a villain —
And fell murderer should.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: More charity for shame.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Sorrow gripe my heart till it be blood less,
But what thou speak'st is false:
A more slanderous lie never left the lips of any.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Lie?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Sir, be persuaded.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Tell not me, I'll prove it on him, Arbaces, boy —

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: That we were alone.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well said, old lad.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Show thyself a man, meet me tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good, sir, forbear.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Not meet him.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Will you be entreated?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Give me leave.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Will you be pacified?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Meet thee, yes I will meet thee;
I dare meet a man: Arbaces thou shalt find it.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Come, you are a prater.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Prate; ye shall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: With reverence of your age, good sir,
You want of that discretion and staid judgement;
Your years and place requires: it is not well,
One of your reputation and report,
Should so forget yourself: to be plain,
You lack advice; and this same cavillation,
Merely provoked by you.
Proclaims a loud your inconsiderate folly.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Sir, sir; check your own: —
You never lost a son, and cannot
Aim at my affections and paternal care:
You have undone me —
Robbed me of my joy.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: You are not right considerate,
Who has undone you sir?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: You, you, and she, and every one of you;
The punishment for murder fall on all your heads,
And blast your terrene hopes:
Cruel, cruel, butchery.
Wast not sufficient that he took his life,
As by his own confession:
Undid his woeful mother and myself,
But he must practise more
Immanly, more dire austerity;
Throwing his breathless trunk
In some obscure night-shaded mansion,
A prey for ravenous beasts;
Where never eye of creature rational,
Shall more behold him: unchristian part,
If there be justice, above or here;
As certainly there's both: I'll petition,
my loud complaints shall pierce both sides o'the globe,
And strike a sorrow in the rudest thing,
Nature for man's use moulded:
O! my Antonio? my joy, my life;
My dear, my dear Antonio.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: There's cause for this.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Sure, sure, how fond was I
That could not weigh this before;
Having his proper cause,
If for some not slaughtered,
Nor mine own, but by selection,
I could sigh my age, shed floods of tears,
Meet dangers in my shirt, bid conquering
Death defiance, if all this and more I durst attempt,
For one no otherwise, then mine by law;
Needs must he rave past rules of manhood,
And forget all precepts that support his sufferance:
See you this? What think you of yourself?
Have you not done well? account thou scandal,
That like the whore of Greece,
Was teemed for man's destruction;
Thy sin upon thyself, my door is shut;
That hospitality I show a stranger,
Shall be restrained from thee.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Most courteous sir, — expect more.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Keep your orisons to charm relenting beggars.
Such in need, as may thy wants relieve;
Or at least sympathy thy mournful tale,
When fierce distress smiles,
Expect more comfort from the blustering North,
When he does blow the highest acorn head
Down to the meadow, and there dips his cup;
Then lest relief from me, for thee;
For thee chaste maid, all benisons,
And goodness, that I can, command and have.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Your liberality was ever such,
As merits more than thanks; yet thus far,
truth emboldens me to say you are too cruel kind,
Not all the proofs,
Whate'er incensed my brother to his rage;
Can wean me to that vain opinion,
To think it her desert: I dare protest for her,
No persuasion can drive belief in me,
To call Antonio false; if you prove so cruel,
So unnatural as you speak, there is no pity in you:
Nor are you such as a father ought to be,
Thrust her out, then turn me off;
If you supplant one, you extirp us both,
And her extremes are mine.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Since you disdain my proffered courtesy,
Together shelter your necessities;
Take up your harbour with the hardy beast;
These gates are locked to her and her relievers
Henceforth I will forget her,
Blot her name forth of the bed roll
Where my children stand,
And vow I had none such:
Hence, hence, thou scandal.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thus guilt less ones, suffer the guiltless blame,
While they triumph in fraud, thus the strict judge
Condemns th'innocent for the thief's offence;
Whilst partiality allows his wrong,
And greatness makes it good;
Will equity never take place again?
Has trust left swaying here? that I but knew my crime:
Or that Francisco but beheld my heart!
Let mine eyes rain a river of salt drops,
And my tears drown me, if any foul sin of mine,
Deserve Francisco's hate:
I had rather heaven had made me any thing,
Then one so much unhappy,
When ere thou bidest on the plenteous shore,
Or labouring flood,
Prosperity adhere to thy proceedings,
and fame conclude thy deeds,
For me despised, such be my fortune as my loyalty,
And I request no more,
My sweet, my sweet Francisco.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Heaven do thee right.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And if thou beest not honest,
There's neither pride nor cozenage in this city:
If every conscience were well searched,
And you did not find
Some dainty fine conceited rogue
Has been tempering,
Let me return to my cradle,
And be hanged in my swaddling clouts.

div.head: Actus tertius. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Vallentius, and doctor's wife, Lodowick, Tomaso, and Julio.

sp.speaker: Tomaso.
sp.p: Think you it so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, and verily believe't.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: 'Tis strangely carried.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mark the end, mark the end;
Why do you sigh, signior?
Are you troubled with the cramp?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: O, blame him not, he has good cause to sigh,
Francisco set by him precious: how fare you, signior?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Never worse, my friend's undone.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Ay, a mischief and a vengeance oth' cause, by this sword, nay, fear not man, I am not angry, and I could not judge, well, I say no more: but if he did not walk on
stilts, I do detest eating and drinking, and those are two necessaries, a man can hardly live well without them.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: The very paragon, mirror of the time.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If I could not have wept when I beheld her, and that was more than I did at the death of my father, I have no belief in me.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Who but she, the wonder of our age.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No more words, mark the end, mark the end; I say, still mark the end.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not as the wench left the Frenchman in the suds, there's neither mettle nor society in thee; if thou abandonest my company, till we have visited Valentius.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: I wonder how he speeds?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Did he not act the madman to the life, was't not well? could ever a dunstical doctor in this town, have picked falsehood out of his behaviour: he was so mutable, so full of varying tricks ( methinks ) I see him yet.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Defer your visitation till tomorrow, or late sometime tonight : I am yet unfit, this sudden trouble has made me not myself.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, you must go; I have sworn you shall, and (That presently.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: I pray you pardon me,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I will not be denied, refuse me now and ever.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: You'll have your humour still?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, eschew acquaintanceship? forget, after my most hearty commendations, my very trusty friend, 'twere sin and shame Tomaso.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: But some other time.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This time, sometime, other times, and all times, this day, yesterday, tother day, and every day; no hour amiss, march on, march on.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p:
I could launch my dagger through my side, at one easy throw: beggar my friend; subvert mine own estate, and undo her, by whom I hope to climb, accursed, brainless slave: could the damned devil with all his firebrands, beat into my pate no sounder subtlety. I had, I had relief, fool
vaunt of that? ▪ boast what thou hadst? or might have? 'tis past, 'tis gone, my villain self, confounded has myself, and him that did sustain me:
sp.l: What chokes corn sooner than side-feed weeds,
Who ofter does man wrong than he afeeds:
Let me ponder; have I no other invention?
No trick to take away my life, after my means:
Study upon't, I'm struck upon a sand,
Swallowed, devoured, through wilful ignorance,
Never to rise again: 'tis a villain's cast,
First to sink others, them himself at last.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You cannot blame me neither:
For love himself undertook more for love;
Had you been tangled in a labyrinth more intricate
Than held the minotaur, or have been
By enchantments bound to servitude,
My life's adventure had my love expressed,
And offered the release.

sp.speaker: Doctor wife.
sp.l: Our plighted amities will dwell in me
While life endures; the many winters, and the tedious hours
We two have spent alone, alone Vallentius,
When nothing but what was not fit the sun
Should look upon, — alack my husband.

div.stage: Enter doctor, Thomaso, Lod wick, Stultissimo, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It must not be denied, I'll maintain't before the synod, here's my witness: was't not well done of brave Caligula to make his horse a senator? deny't, deny't, would not a good horse show well among a team of asses: ha, what think you: give me another sword: oh noble Hector, look, Achilles flies, and bloody Pyrrhus shrinks.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What news, what news?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Gentlemen he takes me for a carrier:
You are deceived sir, I am not the party.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will Pluto keep his word, shall all extortioners, engrossers, usurers, be finely damned, of what kind soe'er? will he spare none?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Wondrously spent.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Let me see, let me see, the son of Panace, a sprightly lad; Hercules, a lusty youth, a very lusty youth; Sampson, a tall young man, a very tall young man.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Does he not do't well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll make thee prove't, I'll make thee prove't.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I think you are mad:
What shall I prove?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why greatest generals, that command whole legions, and train, and keep in order every man, cannot keep in a woman.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: That's an easy question, because most of them get follies wings, and grow so light there's no ho with them: they must fly out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hang them, they are naught all: tell not me learned Ovidius Naso, what's your name.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That bloody villain: treason gentlemen, call up a guard, the traitor's discovered: bind him sure, sure: are you took napping sirrah: down with him, down with him, down.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Help, help, help gentlemen.

div.stage: Vallentius beats him in, the gentlemen would come between. Exit all but the doctor's wife.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I do not like this.

div.stage: Enter Valentius again, and kisses her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now my sweet I have sent him off in post,
Let us retire the while.
Who in affection will not his wits prove,
Was never loyal, nor did ever love.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p:
Past, past cure, I doubt. Give me leave, I find by
my art 'tis no vertigo, no whirling, but a mere settled frenzy: nay I pray you give me leave: for as both Hippocrates, and Galen, Avicen, Podalirius, rucis, Cornelius, Celsus, Corannus, Augustino, and Rombart, do you conceive me? besides a dozen or two of Englishmen, most learned and worthy physicians (If I knew what they were) have demonstrated paraphrastically, both it and the cause, styling the malady the digestion of the brain, or irrevocabilis ignis, the irrevocable fire: nay, will you understand me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Would we could.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I pray you give me leave.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Who hinders him?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Sir if you can speak our tongue, I would very fain be beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Not altogether mad, though I confess I have been pricked with the thorns of love: I have been over shoes in my days.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Avoidance, for charity avoidance.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Yes marry shall you: I would desire you to help me to a pill, or a potion that could make one honest, that I doubt is a little gone astray.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Avaunt, avaunt.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: No sir, she is none of my naunts: she's one that must be my wife.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Turbulent fiend: avaunt, avaunt I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: I would have it applied sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Illiterate dunce, abandon my house, avaunt I say again.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you be quiet, for though I have endured many hard words at your hands, I shall hardly brook blows.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Good gentlemen give me leave to laugh: ha, ha, ha, the doctor's wife, and the madman: the madman, and the doctor's wife.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Why sir, the fits upon him, and he's upon her, and yonder's such sport, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Fire and thunder.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Run: beware horns.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Is this true sirrah?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Follow the doctor, believe your eyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Beware the trap Valentius.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Pray heaven he be not ta'en with nibbing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why are you melancholy signior?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Faith sir i' me troubled with corns, and ever against rain they make me so melancholy —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is that it, for the thing you spoke on, you shall not be beholding to the scald peremptory doctor: come to my chamber anon, and I'll give you a powder shall fulfil your request, as well as all the potions or pills he can devise.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Nay, but will you be constant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Say no more:

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: And you do take my word, while I live: she and I will be at your service: when shall I come for't?

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.l: Any time afternoon . Will you walk Tomaso?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: This is good news withal my heart: Fub we are all made; thou shalt have a new livery out of the bargain.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I thank you sir, I would I had it.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Thou shalt, that's as good: would I were whipped but I could be monstrous merry now.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: No I pray you be not monstrous merry till you are married.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: I'll go give thee a pottle of sack.

lg.head: The tavern scene.
lg.l: And ever he gave her a bob,
And ever he gave her a blow:
But where he knocked her once above,
He thumped her thrice below.

sp.l: What wil't not do? prithee let's— be lusty.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: As a crow in a gutter. Run there she goes.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, and the old shepherd disguised.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Father, for so I must style you,
your care and pains in my recovery,
Deserves a recompense more than I am able to perform:
Now I consider with myself, had we compassionate souls,
Or were men but good, they would banish beggary
The world quite over, and every one have sufficient.
As hitherto you have concealed my course,
Continue still your wonted secrecy,
Call me your son, and such appointments as a father
Should command me to endure I shall perform:
Blessed, blessed be you: effectual be my prayers.

sp.speaker: Shepherd
sp.l: The longer time you so journey here with me
The more welcome: nothing more I crave;
But if I die while you reside i'th' grove,
Out of your charity you'll take the pains
To lay me in the grave I have prepared, and with your hand,
Your foot, or any thing, cast dust upon my body,
And spend a little ceremony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: More than this I will, and more than I will speak.
Francisco, wheresoe'er thou bidest, abide in quiet,
And have my pardon ever. If thou beest fled
For any cause of mine, and I thy ruin prove,
Defend it heaven, were't not for trial of Phemone's love,
And promised constancy, how soon would I renounce
My habitation, unclothe thy fear, and set all even again?
Nothing 'Mazes, nor drives me into that serious
Contemplation, as whence his wrath should proceed.
Perchance Franciscus thinks me unfit to call him brother,
And his sudden rage proceeded from advice.
If it be so for ever will I keep this shady bower,
And never hold companionship with man,
More than is present, forget Arbaces ever
Called me his, or that I was his son.
Circle me safety, what are these come here
Where never neighbour dwelled?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Calamity could not inflict so much as I could bear
With patience, did Franciscus imagine but the truth:
No lenity, but all extremes that may
attend me with their sharpest violence,
If e'er I broke my vow: this sorrow,
Nor the behaviour I sustain are for mine own endurings,
Witness you that know all secrets, 'tis for him
I wish thrice better than myself.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and that Cornelia; as sure as the black ouzel
Has a yellow mouth, that whistles me awake.
'Tis she, or I am fond.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: O my Franciscus! O my dearest lord!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There needs no more for confirmation:
What make they here? Do not undo me wonder.
Never had two ragged coats more orient pearls,
Than you two shells do hide: 'tis she, or I am fond,
Leap not forth with joy, such needy robes
Should wrap the shoulders of necessity,
When winter falls the leaf: happy Antonio,
I am disguised, and so, if that my speech reveal not,
Without suspect I may obtain my wish,
And have all doubts resolved: I'll greet 'em.
Bonny wight, whate'er you be,
Luck be in your company:
Are you Sylvanus, say to me?

sp.speaker: Phem.
sp.l: None such, good shepherd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Deft and trim ones mickle glee,
Be you what you please to be,
Some disaster tend by ye,

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Never, never more.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: A me unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Welladay, now by my creed,
And my merry oaten reed,
Sike another rousing sigh
Would well split me gay and blithe:
Let a loutish clown partake,
Why this sobbing dole you make?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: O inconstant world.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: A me unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wonderment of woe relate
if simpleness you might not scorn,
How you happed to be forlorn.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: The story would be too tedious for the time,
And would undo the speaker: friend no more,
You shall do well to leave us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be not all too keen, bright star,
If my pertness went too far,
Mercy is the doom I sue,
Good things never meant more true,
Than the silly shepherd did,
Late when he your sorrow bid:
Discourse the means merry pan,
And the sagest gods do scan;
Wherefore was it? well a near,
You foul mucky cloud I fear
Will besprint us, Poebus twain,
If so list you but to deign
A poor shepherds entertain,
Welcome should you be, I wiss,
Nor thing comely should you miss,
Though not courtly: answer make,
Will you my small feasting take?

sp.speaker: Phem.
sp.l: The rain begins to fall;
Sister accept the shepherd's courtesy,
His simpleness cannot but mean well sure.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Even what you please:
Whither I go, or wheresoever I rest,
Sorrow with me, and I with sorrow feast.
Welcome, welcome, welcome still,
Never with a freer will
Was welcome spoken, by the sky;
Welcome, welcome heartily.
Alack, alack, the rotten South
Begins to open his dewy mouth,
Time to hide you: father meek
Give kind welcome, I beseek,
To these white ones, bonny girls,
Welcomer than heaps of pearls.

sp.speaker: Shepherd
sp.l: You see our cave, and make as bold as welcome.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Receive my adorations Queen of chance, thou never gavest that jewel to that man, was half so well esteemed; my hopes have their desires, Phemone, blessed success; nothing that's amiss, but I shall understand: disguise I thank thee, joy ties up my tongue, and will not let me speak; they part not soon.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What angle of the earth must be my grave?
The sea and sun have bounds, and know their course,
The sons of men have none:
Limitless he wanders the foreign deserts,
And begets more wonders every hour:
The chime that tells the last minute of the night,
Chides but in vain when every thing's asleep ;
So I in the relation of my woe, when no man hearkens,
Spend but idle breath, and never find relief.
But for increase sake, I could wish devoutly,
I never had known woman:
What comfort ever others reaped from them,
They have been plagues to me: to note the difference,
They are such things, nothing's more worse, nor better;
To say truth, they are angels, and devils;
I will not curse 'em, lest I make them worse
That needs no badness, nor rip up their defects,
Lest I spend all my after time of life in nothing else but that.
Julio, the profit of my Orisona be thine,
Where'er I spend 'em, upright constant man:
Yet I am eased, in that I do not bear my slavish yoke,
Cocker mine infamy, as many do within our Venice gates:
Thanks to thee Julio; chastity, honour of women,
Whither art thou fled? that they are all so false
I must forget 'em, they will make me mad
To think of their abuse: would I could learn
what inquisition is made after me;
Some speech of my concealment will report blab out,
That I may hear the danger does pursue me,
Though I adventure life, I will know more,
Or die in the presumption: I'll nearer to the city.

div.stage: Enter Lodwick, Tomaso, Julio, Stultissimo, Fub, the whore, and the bawd.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: That's a good jest i'faith; drawer, gives more wine.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's a good jest signior?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: That none should be honest but the valiant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How's that? how's that?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Why my beetle-browed host swears 'tis impossible for any to be honest, that is not valiant.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: What said he? What said he?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: That none could be honest, that were not valiant.

sp.speaker: Tomd.
sp.l: O very good, very good: more wine here, he's packing, set out his hand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And his foot too, ere I have done: where's this fellow? another pottle sirrah.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Sir I thank you for my powder, it gave her half a dozen of tickling stools, she has been loose ever since.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Give me your hand, here's even now to all the invisible horns i'th' city.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Forget not the country, let it go round I pray you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A health.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: You'll have reason to pledge this shortly.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Will you come? tomorrow is the day I'll assure you, for better or worse.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tomorrow from better to worse?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Yes faith he has said it, and I swear it, from better to worse indeed.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Married tomorrow signior?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: You have said we shall be doing.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Undoing he means.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: So near marrying Clariflora, and not acquaint your friend? i'faith I thought mistress you would have let me understood what had passed.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: 'Tis my part to conceal.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: She were no good bawd else.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come, sit round, sit round, tomorrow the day?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Pardon me, I'll not sit next this lousy fellow: gentlemen, what do you with this poor rogue in your companies? Does he come to make mirth, can he play the fool wittingly?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know him not.

sp.speaker: Toma.
