sp.l: Would he were set down stairs, I never could endure him from the first: Franciscus made me know him.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Sirrah, if you mean to depart in peace, begone suddenly.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Would the ass could rid this intruding copesmate.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Let me beseech you.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: You shall go, your prayers cannot save you; Fub, show him the way down.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Shall I be your usher? will you follow your leader sir?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Thus poverty's despised at home, abroad, and in all companies.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: A whoreson tatterdemalian, come amongst gentlemen of sort. What, is't no more but up and ride? How now Fub, is he vanished?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: The drawers have drawn him out sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Clinke boys.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Drink boys.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: And let the cannikin clink boys.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Stultus.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Yes Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tomaso, shall's make a night on't mad lads?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: And a mad night too bullies: where shall's strike fail?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
The leaguer, where but a'th' new leaguer: there's
generous entertainment for gallants of sort at all times: and for entrance trust me my mates.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: But money grows low, and expenses will fly high.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Fly high, let it, I have a jack in a box shall pay for all one day.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am as full as a sponge, I cannot sink up a drop more.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: No matter, we can squeeze some more out thus: we can wake the constable, trouble the neighbours, disquiet the master and whole family, spill his wine, puff his tobacco, foul his rooms, practise who shall break most holes, and cleanliest, in the bottom of quart-pots, with a piece of a tobacco-pipe: cry good morrow mine host, we ha' made a mad night on't I vow, and so trance; we are no gallants and we cannot do this.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But this course is either conscionable, or commendable.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Faith 'tis the course, most of the cork-headed candle-snuffs walk in these latter days, late at nights.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, let them rest: so, ho, the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Munk.
sp.l: Chi-va-lah.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Amice.

sp.speaker: Munk.
sp.l: The word.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pecima largienda.

sp.speaker: Munk.
sp.l: Let 'em pass: down with the portcullis:
Lights and attendance, welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I ever said, it might come in a night, that came not in an age, et ecce noctem faelicem; see, that jovial night is come: they have been playing high, and potting deep: lights, wine, and more stools for these gentlemen; welcome.

div.stage: Enter Lodowick, Tomaso, Stultissimo, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tomaso when's the day?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Assure's this the night before tomorrow, I have brought in my estate a matter of 400 pound per annum, in deeds, leases, fee-simple, and copyhold already: and that's no simple estate you'll say: I mean to bid you welcome to a leaguer of mine own shortly gentlemen; some wine you scoundrels.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'm pleased to here't, whose faults this, yours Tomaso?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: What's this leaguer raised yet, par la ho boy, I thought we should have had a second siege of Troy on't, is their reckoning paid? not a penny, they called for one, but in such a drunken key; I bade 'em sleep upon't, and I would tell 'em more on't when they were sober.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Best of all, and what's to pay then?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Nine and six pence, sir, allowance for lights, linen, coals to light faggots: and six pence for one journeyman's sleep only deducted, and yet they grumbled too.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: But nine and six pence, and grumble; my friend the reckoning's not paid you say.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Not a penny.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The reckoning but nine and six pence, how poorly this shows, in a leaguer too, and friends that pretended me a courtesy too? How many joints of meat to supper?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Only a couple of clean pipes, some three times filled I think.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: No meat, come to handsel a leaguer, what no meat? Are they a-bed at Anthony's ordinary yet?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Two hours ago.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Step down, and see, nine and six pence, they must and shall hear more of this: we may go beg, or buy up all the, refuse, broken bread and meat, scraps, offal, and garbage that cooks shops, shambles, ordinaries, entries, and rich-men's doors afford; nine and six pence, if they do not hear more of this —

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: 'Tis past that time of night; charity's bed, sir, but if not. —

sp.speaker: Breadman
sp.l: Bread and meat for poor prisoners, bread and meat.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: What doth that fellow cry?

sp.speaker: Breadman
sp.l: Bread and meat for the poor prisoners, bread and meat.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: For poor prisoners? as fit for my purpose, as a coney for a pursnet; here, take money, buy his provision by the lump: if I had studied for a fortune to fall upon me, I could not have had a fairer.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Wilt thou victual thy leaguer with scraps, sweet chuck?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: No, my sweet monkey, I have further aims than so, this broken meat and baggage offal, will I strew in my kitchen, dressers, hall, entries, and every door and draw-window, and perspicuous places about the house: foul all the vessel, three or four times over, all to besmear the rusty spits and dripping-pans; break all my broken glasses, beat the bottom out of my cans: beat all my foul tobacco-pipes, into fractions

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: And to what end all this?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Perlahay, my friends shall hear more of that in the reckoning: my sweet monkey, when the drunkards shall wake, and see all these ruins, or rather remains of a plentiful leaguer: o, hast thou no apprehension? Why, I tell thee, they cannot choose out of their generous bounties, but see all discharged?
sp.l: Within. A cup of six, drawer.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: O, the leaguer begins to rise! Come monkey a few directions for you in private, give you attendance on the leaguer; let 'em call for what they will, and want nothing they call for: only I will tell 'em no more of nine and six pence in the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: But for the nine and six pence.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Monkey, you shall hear more of that anon, when they are sober? why drawer, dog, dunghill-raker; is the leaguer dry? By and by, a cup of six into the low leaguer, there.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: So, ho, the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: What do ye lack? by and by, do ye call gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: No, and I called a gentleman, he would answer me, I call a drawer goodman rascal, art thou one?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: For fault of a better, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Couldst not ha' said so then? where's the master of the Leaguet?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Parlahey monkey, bene venu gallants, come a stato sigiores mio come i stato.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Marry the better for your entertainment; thanks, sir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Thank him, I scorn to thank him, I'll pay him, and be out of his debt: come, to pay? A reckoning drawer.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: You rascal, who takes away here? here's a house bestrewed with garbage and offal, as if the great inquest had been feasted, etc.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: As good men, to no man's dispraise be it spoken, where's a bill?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Prithee knock us not down, afore our time; was this certain feast of our making? what a spoil of poultry has here been? Tomaso, I must be beholding to thee for this ordinary.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Some small trifle Stultissimo, the reckoning is thought to be.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: The reckoning's very high, nine pound six shillings.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Nine pound six shillings, Parlahey, and yet I use you like Christians too boys.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nine pound six shillings, how could we four devour so much being half drunk when we came in?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Why there's the mystery? you fall asleep with meat in your mouths, my mistress and I stood it out.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Wast not an excellent swan-pie? Servant.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: As ere swam in mill-dam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nine pound six shillings, one lay out for all,
come, your purses gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: And you love me, let me have the credit at this time there's: ten pounds, give me the rest again (Ah, we had the bravest marchpane, and sugar-candy custard) or do not, let it run on towards fouling of linen, and paying for sawee: the rest again, or do —

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I do not think but you are sawest pretty well already, for the devil a bit of meat saw I, and yet all these scraps could not come of nothing.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: The reckoning's paid to a hair, come let's withdraw (But while the room be a little finificald.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Parlahey, welcome gallants to the leaguer still: please you withdraw.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We accept it thankfully.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Whose fault's this yours Tomaso?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: There wants lap.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Throw down the pottle pot, let's have a gallon more.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: Will't please you gentlemen, to hear any music ▪ and a good song?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Very fain, a good one.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: What's your fellows, whose noise are you?

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: Rubert's noise, and please you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Call your fellows, and strip your tools.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Here's to you signior.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: A brace of them if you love me.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Marry and shall.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Score a gallon of claret in the pomegranate.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: What Tim?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Master Fub I rejoice to see you well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You are not merry gentlewomen, mistress durable what, no mirth?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: And how is't, how have you done this seven years, welcome again.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: As you see, in perfect memory, when shall we ride the hogsheads?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Ha, do you remember that night, ancient thumps health overthrew me, my master goes out of town next week; i'faith and you'll come, there's half a dozen good boys, we'll be swinging merry, will give him a crash, old will, will be here?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: What will?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Little will of the mitre. O, master Fub, sir, out maid, that gave us the neat's tongue is gone.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: See, see.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Some sugar there?

sp.speaker: Fiddler.
sp.p: Ha, ha, hum.

lg.l: In ample storeys written 'tis,
Who list but for to mind it;
How loved Narcissus?
Go look and you shall find it.
This echo was a nymph most chaste,
A lack, the more the pity ▪
She should be so, and should not reap ▪
What follows in my ditty?
Narcissus was but young, I wiss,
But yet of perfect feature,
And had enough to satisfy
A reasonable creature.
His brawny limbs became his parts,
No one of sense could blame them:
And so did something else I trow,
Echo knew how to name them.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: A virtuous piece of matter, gentlemen, we'll no more on't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, hold up, signior.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Bid her hold up, fear not me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come gentlewomen, shall we have a dance? Tomaso what say you?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You prevented me.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: I thought it should have been my motion?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Wherefore ring those bells?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Bells, you are deceived, it is the clincking of pots.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I would have sworn, it had been coronation day.
Masters, can you play us Gascoyne's Whibling?

sp.speaker: Fiddler.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Let's have't.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Here lacks a couple, we cannot dance it.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Lack a couple, what serve Tim and I for?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Tis true, well remembered.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Truly, master Fub, I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Truly, you shall learn then.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: I shall be willing to endeavour.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Strike.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: I'll throw the pot at his head that strikes here,
Who's that will strike?

div.stage: He drinks all the while they dance.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Rare i'faith, give's more wine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What, Timothy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: By and by.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Look to the lion.

div.stage: He rises and throws down the table.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: I'll have my galliard too

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: You spoil all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How does your head, sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Yes faith, and thank you too, what rogue's he that turns the room round? shall we not quench our thirsts before we part?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What else my sweet signior, this is your servant?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Good enough for a property, he will serve my turn, as well as a better, I shall but use his name: do you think I would marry the coxcomb, but only for colour and fear of the law? I'd see him baked first.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: 'Tis wisely done of you? and so my gossip slight could say I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Boy, another quart, and bring a reckoning. Here sir.

sp.speaker: Fiddler.
sp.l: Heaven keep your worship.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: In honester company.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Fub, call for a looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Did you go the right way?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: It's a cup of neat wine, I'll assure —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mistress to yourself, and to our next meeting?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What's to pay?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Nine and six pence, and you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: How comes that to pass?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Here's seven groats glasses.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: No less, I'll assure your worship.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come your money, signior —

div.stage: Let's take away and pay together.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Fub, discharge it Fub.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Some lights, show the gentlemen.

div.stage: Enter and follow with a letter from Vallentius.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Fub, I am e'en as full as a toad.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Yes, sir, but do not spit your venom.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Prithee give me another sip. I am as dry as a cook.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: So I think.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: A pox a this megrim.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What's here, I prithee mark Tomaso: Lodwick, I have my desire: fetch me off speedily, lest I cure the doctor? yours Vallentius, lest I cure the doctor.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What should he mean by this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why, belike he has infused his fit into him, and the physician's turned patient?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: That's impossible?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But for Valentius.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: We must redeem him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What else.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Heyda, is the wind in that door?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: A link good Tim, a link.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Here's one ready, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Signior, good night.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Not a drop more i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: We'll take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: When shall we see you?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Sometime tomorrow, if my father send not.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Good night master Lodwick, good night good, sir.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Good night Tim, remember Friday.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: I warrant you, forget not to bring Hugh, welcome gentlemen.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the doctor and his wife.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I speak't in thunder once again, no more: thou Babylonian strumpet, in thunder I command thee thou lump of sin, no more.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Have patience, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I roar it in thy ears, once more aloud, no more: cannot I deal, but you must be applying, you must be tampering, you must minister: have you not pills for potions? do you not traffic? do not you exchange merchant?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Good Vanderman.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sorceress, I defy thee, and thy deeds of darkness.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Hear me, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I have heard and seen too much, has he not paid you soundly for your pains: no, has he popped you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You are deceived.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You say very true, I am deceived indeed, and fubbed, and gulled, and rid, and you are rid too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Here blow it abroad, there's horns enough to do't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why are you thus impatient?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Dainty fine i'faith, very dainty. Whore thou hast made me monstrous, and I may challenge giants: yes, he shall be your madman; do you not like his fits, do you not, do you not?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Good morrow to you both.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Why should this be?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How do you sir? how does your patient?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Are you not satisfied? am I a stale? must you have new-found crochets?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Do you hear me sir: is he recovered ▪

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Homo armatus, a man armed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Have you heard the like?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Methinks 'tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And when, when shall he plant again?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I wish you would understand me, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Here's a fruitful soil.

sp.speaker: Tom:
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sir, I will be heard, and understood:
Save you lady:

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: More furies, might, and secrecy, whoredom and the every bring all to confusion.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Would we had more of this: we'll see what will come of all.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I perceive Vallentius was i'th' right, he's mad indeed:

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Good morrow gentlemen: I have good news for you; your friend is well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your tidings makes us happy, and gives us a moiety of that content which nothing can do more.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I shall rejoice to see him what he was, and master of that temper he commanded, when he did dare the vaunting bajeset for taxing his belief.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tomaso, Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Valentius.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: I am glad to see you once again yourself.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You're welcome to your wits.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: When time and place shall serve, my wit shall thank you I am ever bound to you sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Hark you Lodwick, are not we partly bawds?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Faith in one kind, we have a snatch that way.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: So I say partly.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I must confess, partly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not remember you, have not that bad opinion, do not think I can be one so false by this kiss.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sibylla.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Ay me, my husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Once again and part.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sibylla.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Farewell, Valentius.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A thousand take with thee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What, hungry still Vallentius, that you cast such a greedy eye that way?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How is't man? what in a trance?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And kinder far than fair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, shall we have a pamphlet; that he begins to study? do you hear Valentius: here's a friend of yours would speak with you, when you are at leisure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I crave your pardon gentlemen, as I live she is —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's this to the purpose?

div.stage: Enter Julio, and the mercer with his man.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: You know my price: for the fineness of the silk, the working of the stuff, and the pleasantness of the colour, the whole street shall not afford you a better, I'll assure you 'tis died in grain.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The better for him that shall wear it, nothing but what's in grain can please him: let me see, I know not how my money will reach: the silkman hath emptied my pocket this morning, but you will bate nothing of your price?

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.l: I protest sir, I cannot, and save by it, and I know you would not wish me to be a loser.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: By no means, I would have every man to live and thrive by what he professeth, it is mine own case: let me see, I cannot make up the sum, I pray you let one of your men step over to the next lane: I lie there at the barbers, I'll dispatch him presently.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: My servants are all busy for the present, you see my shop is full of customers, and every one striveth who shall be first served.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: And I am in haste too, for I have sent for my tailor to meet me at my lodging, and I am loath to disappoint him, because I would have his opinion in the stuff.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.l: I pray you, sir, be expeditious, and my man shall be with you by that time you have told out the money.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: I am much obliged to you as a stranger, I care not if I accept —

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.l: Dispatch me that customer quickly, and follow this gentleman to his lodging: you hear where he lies.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Yes, at the next turning?

sp.speaker: Mercer's man.
sp.l: I'll but fold up this boult of satin, and be with him instantly.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Turn by the next lane, and thou shalt be sure not to miss it, though thou findest not me, I have taken sufficient order and you shall be sure to be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.l: We have many cheapners, but few buyers, many such customers as this would make quick riddance.

sp.speaker: Mercer's man.
sp.l: What comes the sum to, sir.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.p: Three yards of satin and a half at seventeen, eight yards of plush at four and twenty; nay, there are divers other parcels, the sum is soon cast up: thou shalt have a note of all.

sp.speaker: Mercer's man.
sp.l: And I'll but fold up these few bolts lie loose, and clear the counter and be gone.

sp.speaker: Mercer
sp.l: Be quick there.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: But thou must be secret.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: As yourself, sir.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: A pretty handsome youth, and will be loath to discover himself, being extremely bashful, and will make it strange.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Leave him to me, I'll persuade him that I knew him, ere I saw him.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He's my kinsman, next cousin German's by the mother's side; now playing the wag, as many youths will do, you know it barber.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Very well, it hath been many a good man's case.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: He hath got a clap.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: These claps are got by clapping.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: But for one thing, never should it grieve me, I fear it might go never to spoil his marriage, which I would not for more than I'll speak.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: You show yourself a kinsman.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Now his excuse will be (As I told thee he's extremely bashful) to inquire for a gentleman that owes his master money, to comply with the old proverb, though his excuse be draff, yet drinks his errand.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: And lotion must be used.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: As it shall seem best: but thinkst thou he'll endure it.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: 'Twill put him to some pain.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Which I'll not hear, my heart's so tender o'er him: when he comes (As long he will not stay) take him in charge, thy pains shall be well paid, for doubt not but I'll come to the conclusion.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Very good, sir?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: My hope is it will succeed according to my wishes.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Make no doubt of that, sir.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: If I had, I had not made choice of thee above any other.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: You are my friend indeed: and so I hope to keep you.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: I will withdraw for the present, and instantly return.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Now good speed with you, good customers are thick sowed, and come up but thin. It is good to make much of them, when we have them. This should be the patient, that he talked off.

sp.speaker: Mercer's man.
sp.l: I come to seek a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: You do: that owes your master's money.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.l: Very true, sir, you know my errand then.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Before you came.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.l: The gentleman belike hath told it you.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: He hath indeed.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.l: Is he within?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: But before he went, left order with me, you should be dispatched.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.l: Then I shall find him as good as his word: he hath acquainted you with my occasions.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: I'll assure you that, and intends well towards you, I pray come near into the withdrawing room.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.l: I'll wait on you, pray know you what it comes too.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Yes youth, I know, wherefore you come: pray rest you in that chair, and I'll be for you presently; be not ashamed, you are not the first, nor shall be the last, that meet with these disasters: and now come, pray show me your commodity.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.l: The commodity belongs, sir, to my master, 'twas not mine.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Are his in danger too? let him not fear, but if he have not let it run too far, there may be help found: nay, come, will you show?

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.l: Mean you the note: there are the parcels sent.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: These parcels may in time grow great, come, will you be ruled, the gentleman your kinsman, told me before, how bashful you would be; and it becomes you well: but for your parcels, show them in time: for if delay be long, that little which perhaps you shall have left, in time will come to nothing: your kinsman's loath that you should spoil your marriage?

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.p: Spoil my marriage, spoil not my master's debt, neither draw these fearful tricks on me: I need them not, pay me the money that your friend hath left, dispatch me so, for kinsman I have none; and honest barber find some else to sport with, make me none of your gulls?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: But I pray say.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.p: I say, pay me sir, what's my due, and what by your confession, your friend left, or bring me to the party, or commodity he late had of my master, or coin for't: you have confessed him to be your friend, therefore for him must answer.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: By your favour, no more friend of mine, than you found him, to claim kindred: my acquaintance with him, yet is scarce a full hour.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.p:
You are confederates, and so I fear that I shall find you: you know my errand, and promised me dispatch:
why am I not dispatched then?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: My meaning was to give you a sering, or an incision knife, of which he told me you did stand in need: indeed I deal in such commodities, and am acquainted what such parcels mean: for other wares or money due for them, I know not what belongs to't.

sp.speaker: Mercer man.
sp.l: Satisfy my master so, quit me, and clear thyself; or 'twill fall foul upon thee.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Willingly: my cloak boy, I'll along, yet am afraid that he who had professed himself thy kinsman, and my dear friend, will prove thy master's cousin.

div.stage: Enter Lodwick, Tomaso, Stulitssimo, monkey, puss, etc.

sp.speaker: Puss.
sp.l: Give you joy master Stultissimo; give you joy.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: You talk like gentlemen, and I like your talk the better, because you talk to a gentlemen; you call me Stultissimo, and I say, stultorum plena sunt omnia: and now I talk to you like a gentleman and a scholar.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: All health and joy betide you.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Gramercy gentlemen, I am not now the man, I was in the morning; I did rise single, I return double: in the meridian but worshipful, in the afternoon honourable before sunset, and who knows but majestical before midnight: nay I persuade myself I am so: am I not sweet monkey?

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Thou art my dear baboon.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Very pretty names in faith: I prithee let's interchange them still betwixt us: or marmoset, or ape's face.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Yes, yes, by any means.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: All thy goods and chattels, thy movables, and the stuff that belongs thereto, thy utensils and implements; now are all mine.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: They are, to have and to hold.

sp.speaker: Puss.
sp.l: Yes, as long as ye can keep them.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I have purchased thee in thy proper person by my word, but all thy other omnium gathrum, beforenamed, by my deeds, I think thou hast them to show.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: The mind gives sometimes words unto the tongue, and makes it speak perforce, bear with him Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Let the doctor's wife bear with him, for mine own part,
without he renounce this mood, and become sociable, as he had wont, I defy his fellowship.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Will you dine with me Vallentius?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, shall we be merry?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O is the tide turned, is the wind come about, by this good day, and I were not cursing myself, for being accessary to this melancholy, I have no faith in me; if women can transmute men thus suddenly, hang me, if I keep not out of their clutches.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Gallants, shall we walk? I have a story for ye: prithee Lodwick frown not, be a friend indeed, and see not my defects, I have a tale shall make you laugh anon, and will excuse my blame; prithee be thyself, be jocund man.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, I am soon persuaded.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where shall we be?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: At the old house.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come then, I'll make you laugh I swear.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thus by degrees, with hazard of my life, have I attained unto my wishes' rest; and boldly gaze thee Venice in the face: the time has been, o, but that time is past, when I was more familiar with thy pomp, but all that bliss is gone: and murder now, has with a crimson stain sealed me accursed, and like a condemned guilty fugitive; I wander in despair; fearing the rustle of the harmless bird, and the flies clamour, the ant, the wasp, and every lesser thing, dreadless of danger, strays abroad for food; not caring who behold them, but I, alas, of all; am most unhappy: would I were dead, and passed the fear of that, makes me thus cowish. Who art thou com'st here, more needy than myself?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Where might I run to meet destruction, and set a period on my wretchedness? Stern misery I know, and feel thee now: yet is the earth content to bear my weight, and suffer what proud man disdains to know, unless to spit upon, or add to that, which wanteth no extreme.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I cannot hold: his voice, his humour, I dare swear as much, 'tis he; 'tis he by heaven, my Julio.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Franciscus, preserver of my life; oh let me kiss the ground whereon thou treadest, then rise to thank thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
That I could spend myself to tears for joy, bear witness you that know it: Julio, for ever dwell within these arms
of mine, thou truest among men, I have not power to question thee, my danger, my joy is so excessive; run all to spoil, and terror meet with terror; I fear none my julio.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Strike when thou wilt proud death, I dare thee now; for having what I wished, I wish no more, nor would entreat time to defer a minute to have him rest an age, since all things must have end, end it at once, my prayer is confirmed, I have seen you ere I die.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And if you love me wish me not that wrong by praying for your end: do not quite undo me, if you but knew my heart, my julio, you would not crav't again: I could have comfort now, and clean forget the dangers I have passed, and those pursue me still: nothing to come can half so much dismay, as thou dost comfort; be it sudden death or torture worse than it: but for your sake, would in my womb I had been strangled, and never drawn this air.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Where art thou conscience? whither hast thou took since thou didst leave man's breast? that we should all have mothers; wisdom all, yet all contemn her precepts: when you first fled, and by commandment from the senate house, your ships and lands were seized on for the state, those that which stayed them did appear so near, as if their blood had tied them to your service, grew so forgetful in a moment's space, that neither argument, nor extreme signs could win them to belief there had been such, as what you were to them: I (As no less I could) bound to't by duty, spoke your merits still, and did maintain your right, on the allies of your inconstant wife: but I am poor for't, truth was still despised, and less I could not be.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Take all I have ▪ had I my former wealth,
My bounty could not recompense thy worth,
And pour it all before thee (My dear Julio:)
Be not impatient with thy sufferance, he's above will pay thee all
My debts, though I should perish now.
Contemned for me? alack, alack, if there be such
A thing in charity, be charitable: do not curse the cause
Of this thy present want, I do beseech thee do not thou Julio?
I prithee answer me, and either do what I have wished,
Or cure the wound thou hast made.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good sir no more: do not call all the tears out of mine eyes; think who I am: would you did but know.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I will not urge thee further:
Shall we here combine, and shape our course alike,
And never, never part; yet pardon me,
I will not wish thee so much injury
To be unknown of woman.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: You wish me not so well, howe'er you wish, if you wish otherwise: your misery be mine, and my enduring yours; one grave receive our bones; and he that says this sepulchre is mine, call it Francisco's tomb.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have a habit for thee yet unknown, or worn,
But by myself: 'tis not a furlong from the antique beech,
Whose hollow sides conceals it: bide but here,
Till I can reach it from the hidden place,
And take it for thine own: though homely,
Yet the coarseness will keep warm,
And ward the sharpest blast.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: You bind me to my prayers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I'll be with thee straight.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Ignorant honesty, shallow Italian, yes, live a wretch: canst thou be so fond to think me of that mettle? hast thou eyes, and mayst, yet will not see how thou art o'er-reach: yes, do continue innocent, do, and die a fool, my friend, my friend, my very loyal friend, all friendship I forswear, save outward signs, which with my garment i cast nightly off. The father of the slain Antonio promises liberally by proclamation to any that can bring Francisco forth. I will betray him, I will be the man shall purchase the reward: what way I curses, or care for the report the multitude shall clamour therein. I'll imitate the lawyer, making bad words my gain. Franciscus thou wast born for my advancement: he's sunk himself, and fruitless is the hope depends on that which was, and not which is; give me the present, not precedent man. Let me not hanker for emergency, but take the instant sway, the published recompense is mine, 'tis said, 'tis mine.

div.stage: Franciscus puts a coat upon him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That any should be false — but were there no dross, gold could not be esteemed, nor nothing precious rare. Cornelia let me forget that name and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: It is a month and more since she left Venice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Would I had left the world when I first saw her.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: And the same minute did Phemone forsake her friends and kindred: but where or whither they have betook themselves the most knowing but conjecture.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How easy could we make our miseries, if we might live and die when't pleased ourselves?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: These strange additions to my news I add, Antonio's carcase never could be found since yours and his contention.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I left him dead: thou art still just; some beast has made that fouler beast his prey, and made up my revenge: but come with me, let us withdraw unto you thicket by, and speak at large that woeful history commixed of my proceedings, and pursueth; wilt time's our own.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I would provide me of some necessaries, small in expense, which make a mighty miss, and health cries out to have: so if you please but let me fit my present want, at my return enjoin me to your will, though it continue to the latest date, and I am serviceable.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Speak no more such words, but make your own content: yet good Julio be not absent long, make me not long to see thee.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Such shall be my speed, you will not wish me sooner to return.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not wish thee? yes, though thou shouldst make return ere thou depart.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mark the end.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Be brief, and goodness take with thee. This Julio, if desert might purchase fame, deserves sufficient: but thou art partial fortune in cramming buzzards, whilst the eagle starves: how many in this fertile Italy, whom nature moulded when she loathed her task, and blew her seed among the ignorant, hast thou adorned with plenty? whilst seemly virtue, wracked with poverty, jets under base control: there's no felicity, nor true content here upon earth: the spider builds his web in barns and palaces: and the prince himself tastes gall as honey: happiness there's none, for lest or greatest: here my grief so parches me, that it does pain me to relate my woes, and make my feelings known. Beneath this hill a clear and pleasant
fountain curls along, whose shallowness makes the small pebbles 'Pear above like rocks, and murmur as she runs down to the silver current, thither will I high, and borrow so much of her watery store, as will assuage my thirst:
sp.l: All things are kind,
And feed our wants when they themselves are pined.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now my caterwauling puss, how didst thou like my last cheat? did I not fool them finely?

sp.speaker: Pusse.
sp.l: Thou art the very mere Mephostophelus, and I persuade myself thou hast new vampt thy wits.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Tush these are nothing: I have cheated one of the bravest statesmen of the world; the very quintessence of Spain: nay, I have fooled him who boasted in his country, he had gulled all our nation a gelding is not rid in the horse-fair, but he is mine to ride, maugre his master's teeth. I have outfaced a fellow of his horse in the open market, sold him before his face; and but making a question whether he trots or ambles, ride away both with the horse and money, my puss. Sweet monkey look to the house at home, I must abroad again, to fetch in a new purchase.

sp.speaker: Pusse.
sp.l: Mayst thou thrive according to thy will, and to my wishes.

div.stage: Enter Stultissimo, Lodwick, Tomaso, and two sorieants.

sp.speaker: 1. Sergeant
sp.l: And what's your action?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Three hundred pound: be you ready to snap him, and not to escape you without good bail: he's as slippery as an eel.

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant
sp.p: Therefore we'll take him by the shoulder, and not by the tail; and so we shall be sure to hold him. But can you show us the man?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This is his walk, and without waiting long you may spy him.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Say but that's he, and 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Stand as close as you can: if he have but the least suspicion of an arrest, he's gone in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: But will not you stay and assist us?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p:
By no means; I'll but see him in hucksters handling, and be gone. Are you not paid your fees aforehand, and —
that's he now: now let him scape upon your own peril. Farewell.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: If he do, say no more: yeoman stand to me.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Now let me see: whom shall I next encounter?

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Marry the counter sir: for we arrest you.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Ha, counterfeits so nigh?

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant
sp.l: Yet currant enough to carry you to prison.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: And yet your countertenor sounds but like scurvy music: am I catched then? I pray you at whose suit?

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: At three men's suit.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Then three merry men, and three merry men be we, are we not honest sergeants? well, there's a piece to begin withal: let's talk further of the business.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.p: You speak well sir, if you hold on as you begin: and if you can find good bail, ten to one but we shall prove as you late called us (Honest sergeants.)

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Methinks you do not speak like varlets:

div.stage: Enter a grave doctor in serious discourse with a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: May it please you, sir, to employ mine industry for any further service?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Something more,
Which in my former letter I forgotten,
I would entreat you bear in memory:
And that's but this —

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: And in good time: know you that reverend man?

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Know him sir, yes, for a worthy doctor.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: He's mine own uncle: will you take his word.
And make it to me as a free discharge?
If he but say (Nay there's another piece)
I'll see you satisfied?

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant
sp.l: Yes could we hear him say so: for he's one whose word will not be questioned.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: 'Tis enough:
Give me but so much leave as speak unto him,
All I'll keep in fair distance: on my life,
If he say not I'll see you satisfied,
I will return your prisoner.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l:
'Tis enough: for so far we dare trust you: you have
paid for't well: but we will watch him at an inch.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: I know he will not suffer me to lie
For such a petty sum: now brain or never.
Excuse my boldness sir: though it be scarce manners,
To interrupt your serious conference.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: With me sir is your business?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Such a business,
Which as it toucheth me in charity,
So should it you in conscience.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Speak it pray.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Look well on these two men.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: He points at us.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: The one is an arch brownist, and the other
Cannot endure to see a surplice worn:
Subject indeed to no conformity;
Yet both so well persuaded of your learning,
And spotless life, that what you shall propose
They're willing to subscribe too.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I am as ready to give them my instructions.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: And please you say so, that they may hear you sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Well I will:
My honest friends, and please you to have the patience
Till I have ended with this gentleman,
And instantly I'll see you satisfied.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: It is enough grave sir.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Now honest sergeants: what desire you more?

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant
sp.l: Nothing from you sir.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: I hope so honest sergeant: you see I deal fairly.
Farewell my honest sergeants.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I have told you all: only remember me to these my noble friends.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: With all the art
My weak tongue can deliver.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant.
sp.l: So, he is now at leisure.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And now I come to you.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Most welcome, sir, we stay for the same purpose.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Now, tell me briefly, which of you is the brownist?
Which the other, cannot endure a surplice?

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant
sp.l: You are pleasant, sir,
we wait here, hoping to be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And to that end I stay, for these opinions
So erroneous and so gross.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Sir, all the opinion that we hold is that you will pay us the money.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Still obstinate in error; 'tis this money,
And worldly care on which so much you dote:
Breeds in you these distractions.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Please you to pay the money, you shall find us conformable in all things.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Money my friends, are not you sectaries?

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant
sp.l: Sectaries; no, sir, we are sergeants.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sergeants; and wait for me? I owe you money?

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Yes, sir, for your nephew that was with you but now, and told you of it; and we heard you say, you would see us satisfied.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: The man's to me a stranger I protest,
And his request was I should satisfy you
In some points of religion.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Religion, sir, 'tis a theme we seldom think of,
But three hundred pound is money.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: But I tell you,
I passed my word for counsel not for coin,
And this is all that you from me can have:
Endure a surplice, and beware a knave.

sp.speaker: 2 sergeant
sp.l: Had we not warning sufficient of this before?

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Well, howsoever, we have had good counsel,
If we had the grace to follow it.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Arbaces, and Julio in good apparel, with three or four with weapons.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Assure me of the promised recompense, I'll bring you to his presence.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Hear me a word.

div.stage: Enter Vallentius, Lod wick, Tomaso, Stultissimo and Fub.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now signior, how do you feel you self? How like you marriage?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Faith it's a pretty quaint thing, and there's much good sport belongs to't, would I were unmarried again?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why? are you weary of Clariflora already?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Weary no, but I would have store.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Hark you, sir, take my counsel; though store be no sore, meddle with no more of them, lest you make me a prophet, and get many a sore head by the match: have you not heard the ancient saying, no man can serve two masters?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That's true, but any man may serve two mistresses.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: And serve their turns well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, I'll leave that to the performer.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Hark you master Lodwick, you or any man may think he does well, and yet come short.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Briefly, directly, and learnedly spoken, sweet Fub.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I speak by proof.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Go to, you are a knave Fub.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Hold your peace, there's more in the company.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well said, i'faith, thank him Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: It's not worth it, though I should say as much by you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This fellow flows with wit.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Gallants, when were you at court? I have been desired thither forty times, my wife (I think) has a hundred friends there: besides cooks and pantlers, that she has had many a good thing of, and they have sworn to bid me welcome for her sake.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You may see what comes by marriage?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: If we might see all that comes by marriage, there would be old butting abroad?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Here's the sum, perform thy word, and claim it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good morrow, good Arbaces.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Make me not known to these?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Vallentius.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Are you not mad, I heard no less of late.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Report's a calumnious quean, and will abuse virtue itself you see, both what he is, and what he was?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: I am not sorry, that I am deceived: hear you not of Franciscus.

div.stage: Exit Arbaces with Julio, and the watch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Upon my credit nothing.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Fair be your company, come gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's he that throws his cloak about his nose?
Is it not Julio?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: By all exterior seeming?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My life 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What should this mean?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I was asking that.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Marked you Arbaces: he hath some drift in hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did you not note his followers?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes, and the arms they carried.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Shall we trace them, sirs? and leave our wonder: I dare gauge my life, the knowledge will deserve the industry?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You speak my words.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He named Franciscus.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, and questioned me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Withal, observed you but his speed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come, we will pursue him.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: La, la, la, la: nay, I pray take me with you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: If not for company, for mirth's sake, take heed before there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: In mighty men how great appears the virtue ne'er so small; how small the vice, though mighty philosophy, they rules bridles my cogitations, and prolongs, what manhood would disdain, the time to come appalls my courage and strikes instant fears through every nerve and artery: might we like beasts end when we die, and never make account in no other place then here: what heart so base would fear the threatening law? Flatter the judge to save him: I would not sure: but there is bliss and torment much to come, we cannot think on't yet the resurrection awes me, I am much distempered, and want of company, begets in me millions of terrors: Julio tarries long, my orisons secure him, could the tears wash the blood but of my hands, my mind were something free.

div.stage: Enter Julio muffled, Arbaces and a guard.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: This is the place, and there Franciscus walks.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: That's he: apprehend him, I'll not be seen in't.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Your office, sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What are these for men.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Lay hands upon him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What mean you friends?

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.l: This we mean to attach you, as a murderer.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Arbaces, I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.p: Look to the homicide, such mercy as a tiger yields his prey, when he's pinched for want of what's his booty, expect from me thou murderer.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: None I have deserved, or am about to crave, I know the worst, my life thou canst but have, 'tis thine; I make a tender of it ere the sentence come, and give thy labour ease, alas, poor Julio: thou wilt unfriended, run thy future race without society, I pity thee my friend more than myself, danger to me is such, I do expect and dread not. Fare thee well, my breach of promise, is not with my will, but merely on constraint.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Lead him hence.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Here they are.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who have we here bound to the good behaviour? Franciscus!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My dear friend.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: My brother.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Officers, why do you linger thus, away with him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How fare you, sir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sick, sick to death Vallentius: shall we hence?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I now behold my fear, when I did hear Arbaces speak of him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Something of badness shoot me instantly, but he does pierce me through.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Has he resided here since he first fled?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thought him now in Milan, where he did traffic much.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I wonder how he came to be discovered?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Beshrew my blood, I pity his estate.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will you accord with me, show that respect you once did tender him, and withal willingness strive to invent a means may do him ease.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What, my sword, my word, or wealth can do is his, command it for him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let us petition to his rough adversary, and like true suppliants in our own behalfs, draw mercy from Arbaces.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: About it then, and our intentions thrive. Manet Julio.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The gold is mine, his certain bondage does assure me it, why should I be an ass, and nicely stand on that no tradesman does: no thrifty one, what conscience, any thing but such a word: our wise divines that preach an't, know it not, nor make good use of that, or ought they say, but of good money: this I daily see, and sometime make my daily meditation, all's ceremony composed for purpose:
sp.l: But be it what it will, this is my grace,
If not for one, I'm for the other place.

div.stage: Enter the Duke of Venice, two senators, Crissipus, Arbaces, Vallentius, Tomaso, Lodwick, Clarke, and others.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bring the offender forth.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Have mercy, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Believe't thou mayst sooner move a rock, which neither blustering wind, nor boisterous sea could shake or swallow, then beget remorse or smallest favour in so foul a case: I were unjust, and much unmeet to be the man I am, should we show mercy where the crime deserves, beyond the laws extent. He that shall pardon murder, take't from me, is accessary to the guilty deed, and stands in self predicament: heaven defend we should be such, were he my nephew, nay, my firstborn son, or one more near: let me not be blessed in my proceedings, if our authority should blind his sin, or alter justice course, set him forth: what favour equity can yield be his, no more expect Crisippus.

sp.speaker: Pri. Sen.
sp.l: Read the indictment.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Save that pains, guilty, nor do repent, that in my wrath I did, whereof I stand convict.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Art thou not sorry for thy heinous crime?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No mighty sir, but rather joy the more, in that it breviates my passage here, which I would willingly leave.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Impudent homicide: justice good my lord, with that severity which they deserve, which wilfully commit —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Arise, thou needst not kneel, nor beg for justice, be assured Arbaces: such his deservings, such his punishment, and cruel
as the cause, thou most brutish man, nay, beast or something worse: hadst thou no humanity, no spark of reason then, nor sense, to think thy trespass foul and ugly? dost not repent thy tyranny in death, though not the deed itself: fie on thee monster, hast thou a foul and dreadst not her perdition: what heathen savage, nay, what ruder thing, having the life thou soughtst, would have enacted such a deed of ruth, as thou, thou worst of creatures, on the image and liveless carcase of thy loving friend.

sp.speaker: Pri. Sen.
sp.l: 'Twas most uncivil, most unchristianly.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: An act, a tiger would not have performed, on one that had slain his brood.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Hear me good my lord.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: My poor Antonio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That I did take his life, I have confessed, what further accusations laid on me, is merely malice, and proceed from some, could wish my torment worse.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Out on thee butcher: give me leave my lord.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Canst thou deny thy wrathful cruelty, impetuous tyranny, and fell revenge upon his bleeding trunk?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Unless I should belie myself, and speak like a vain boaster, more than what I did, I must say this is false, and he's from truth, as far as I am from hope of life, begotten this slander.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Produce your proof Arbaces, strike blushes through the cheeks of this false man, and let him see his shame.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What devil should be raised from the lowest hell, to justify this wrong?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I never thought Franciscus one so foul, as I behold him now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not thought, I durst have sworn him of a purer mettle ▪ and better temper far.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Prosperity to the Venetian state.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Julio: he's not his proof I hope.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: This is he my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Make room, give way there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How comes this about?

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: The fact's confessed, my lord, what need we further wade into the law, or heap on troubles which we may eschew, upon so plain a case? the crime is murder, murder is confessed, then as you find the guilt, proceed to judgement, and make no further question.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We shall be sudden.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My sentence, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Speak, sir, can you report any thing more touching this business then what already is delivered here in the open court.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: No more or less, then what his own tongue uttered, can I or have to say.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: We were once friends: once had I such opinion of his virtues, my life and estimation were both his, he might command them, much it were to speak of all that passed between us: thus in short, I would some other were compelled to this, which you have tied me too, my nearest friend alive.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Arbaces: was this the man gave you first notice where this murderer kept?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: The same my lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Did he betray me? can this be.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: Speak.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Must we be enforced, what should I speak, he slew him, ripped his bowels, mangled him, and in his wrath, as man will any thing: tumbled his reeking quarters down a vault most steep and loathsome: what of this, he might deserve much worse austerity, yet this was bad enough?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Justice, gracious prince, justice, justice, sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this truth?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Let me be deposed —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The most erroneous, execrable part that ever was performed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Were he my father, should forget himself, and match this outrage, mercy quite forsake me if I would sue his pardon.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: It was ruthless, fell, and bloody.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Look not up for shame, thou hast no interest there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have done wrong, mighty, mighty wrong.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Canst thou behold it now?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pardon me father, pardon good Arbaces: that villain, that foul villain.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, Cornelia, Phemone, and shepherd.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.l: 'Twas time to come.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Show mercy, mercy, Duke.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Pity our complaints, have some compassion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are these that make this earnest deprecation, with such a hearty zeal; are they well known to this assembly?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Cornelia, sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Fair Phemone.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: When will these humid fountains be dried up, and yield no more warm drops?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My sweet Franciscus.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Some good or bad thing fell me suddenly, let me behold no more.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is that his wife?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She was my lord, while some hard fate disjoined their mutual league, and burst the holy concord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Wilt thou pardon me and live a happy one, when I am dead, and leapt in this cold earth.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Franciscus I was ever true to you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I see it, and believe: that villain, o, that villain!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Harken thy sentence.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Hear me my good lord, little I have to say, yet to much grief tend my few words, this traitor, nay, 'tis title all too good for one so heinous foul, that he is perjured, by the death I owe his latest words do witness what he is more, and worse: with pardon lords, I shall delate at large, that all hereafter may example take, and shun a villain's snare; I took him up, when like an adder in the frosty dew, the cold had starved him: that I had set my foot upon his head, when to my bosom I did take the serpent, not cherished, comforted long had he been, but he both bit and stung me: foolish man I was to be so fond, not many months, nor happy days I had with this most truest, most immaculate piece, but that perfidious caitiff, that black fiend by strange suggestions, and invented projects, draws me into a confirmed jealousy, that she had stained her honour, falsely played
with young Antonio.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: O forgive me heaven, what is this?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I from my wrong conceived, lest could I not, drew him apart into a silent grove, having before vowed solemnly revenge, where I made some repetition of my grief: he still (I see him) innocent gentleman, taking my words for such as lovers use, when they are wanton, smiles me in the face, and would not thing 'twas anger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis truth he speaks.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This enkindled me, and as boar,
When he does chaw his foam, predicts some mischief,
So my bent front foretold his ruin,
Forth I drew my sword, and sheathed it
Within his breast, what else is added,
He's a Jew avers, and falser than a whore.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: See, see the age's wickedness: can it be possible?
sp.p: O miserable time, when men make no more reckoning of their souls! Fie, fie, Francisco, think upon your end, and whither you must go. Most reverend fathers, observe you this his contumacy: I shall I fear be forced to speak what in my heart till now I chested, and ribbed in, because mine oath, 'twas not my will hath hear constrained me to expose his blame, my soul had vowed to hide; note into malice how he throws himself, and would stain my reputation with a calumnious lie.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Art thou a man, or something else; o fool, fool.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is this possible?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Give ear unto thy sentence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must, in —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Did not I say he's mad, stark raving mad, away with him. The man's alive that's dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, they supped together: I love this fellow.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Your grace shall do well to punish this saucy groom.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are a most pernicious damned villain, and your soul knows it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Come, sir, depart, and rave not, or I shall see you whipped.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good father pardon; pardon mighty Duke, pardon Antonio, cause of this disquiet. Lod. Antonio?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By this light he supped with him indeed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is not so, this cannot be.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is there no mountain nigh to fall on me, no rotten house?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I know not whether I may call thee son, or rest in doubt for ever.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am Antonio, and I was your son, when I left Venice last.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is no man here amazed but only I?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: My dear Phemone!

sp.speaker: Phem.
sp.l: Were you the shepherd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You see chaste Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Was ever man so blessed?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, come Francisco, I must have your hand: I can as well forgive, as I can love; and nothing more than both: good Crissippus, my old friend.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have been a stranger signior; but I'm glad 'tis thus.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Whither away: stay him officers; we have not done with you.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Whither shall I run to hide myself?
What climate, or what region? Pardon greatest prince.
Pardon grave fathers.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Against that prayer kneel I:
No pardon prince, as thou dost hope for bliss.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Grant him a halter; nothing else good Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Give him his liberty: art thou so impudent to plead for mercy, and beg of me, having committed such a capital trespass here in my view?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Though what I speak, with some additions, I have done and more, and he more false has played, than I have said, blot his offences: be propitious sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Though the greatest sufferance fell on my part, I here acquit him, and beseech for mercy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yet be compendious, and possess this presence, what cause thou hadst that tempted thee so badly to seek my ruin.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: The devil and his angels.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O fie Joretzo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How Joretzo? not the son of that pernicious traitor, had plotted with Lamunes for sums of gold to burn our city?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He's dead, and suffered for the same offence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l:
When brought the toad forth other than himself, unless
'twere something worse?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Forget his father's faults: be pitiful.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: He that prays next in his behalf, by heaven friends not himself, and is mine enemy: we have too long suffered such weeds as these to flourish in our soil: no more the bosom of this earth of ours, shall (Like a mother) lend her fruitless increase, to cherish those would bane her: the sword of justice cut the justice off that keeps it sheathed to such: his deeds were shameful, his rewards be so, and quittance his desert: sear on his brow in letters capital, the name of knave, that all behold may read him what he is, and hate him in the sight: his next doom is this; after three days we charge thee on thy life, never set foot more in thy native climate.
sp.l: So, bear him to his torture, speech is vain:
For what is said there's nothing can restrain.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Most worthy prince.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'll be honester while I live for this trick.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Can you forgive mine injury, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As freely as I hope to be forgiven; and crave no more amends, but only this you'll call me brother, and make Phemone mine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I need not make what's made, take and enjoy her that hath vowed to be none but yours.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Thy hand Arbaces, our quarrel's o'er, we'll no fighting.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Fight, yes: I hope we shall find something else to do.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Daughter I have done thee wrong too; but I'll seek forgiveness when we have more leisure.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This day breeds wonders: by what accident scaped you of your wounds?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here stands the means, whom I must ever tender with respect, as with my full proceedings you shall hear, when none can interrupt.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Francisco, henceforth know your virtuous wife, and prize her as a jewel: I have heard the world speak well of her, and those unmatched wish they may have your fortunes. Lodwick where's the dumb show you promised me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Even ready my lord; but may be called a motion: for puppets will speak but such corrupt language, you'll never understand without an interpreter, or a short plot; which I have drawn
thus — now the motion follows.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: What not divulge: yes, yes, I will divulge.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The jealous doctor: I have him.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Do me right, sweet Duke, do me right.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What art?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: A fool, a physician, a maintainer of whoredom, with a pox to me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then Medice cura teipsum; more knave than fool, the plot's false drawn else: away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come sir, depart.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Purge me Duke, purge me, or let my wife take out my corrupted brains, and rinse them in a cucking-stool: I come Skimmington, I come.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Vallentius you must take some order for the doctor's cure: he befriended you in as great a courtesy.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Trot on afore: is the corn-cutter come yet?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: The horn-cutter is come, sir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: On, on to the leaguer then: I am ashamed to show my head amongst animals: on to the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is a monster of your making, Lodwick, buy him a capcase to hide up his horns in, for shame o'th' world.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come we are both —

div.stage: A great Hubub and noise, a ringing of basons, a great many boys before, and Julio drawn in a cart.

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.l: He comes, he comes.

sp.speaker: 2 boy.
sp.l: Where doth he come? he is rather drawn hither like a bear to a stake.

sp.speaker: 3 boy.
sp.l: What in a coach?

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.p: Nay, rather in an open chariot: and yet it cannot be properly called a chariot, because it runs but on two wheels.

sp.speaker: 2 boy.
sp.l: Room for him there: for I am sure he had rather any here had his room than his company.

sp.speaker: 3 boy.
sp.l: Silence there; you in the docket there, let but one speak in the court at once.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Noverint universi,
It is the Duke's mercy;
And the condition of my obligation,
To make my recantation,
That I within bound,
Should give reasons profound,
Why (Much against my heart)
I thus ride in a cart.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen, no eggs I beseech you: for I love them at this time, neither raw, roasted, nor rotten. For should they hit me on the breast, they would go clean against my stomach.

div.stage: Tomaso in a corner of the gallery.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You Phaeton.
Is that your father Phoebus his chariot, and will he allow you never a box to sit in?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: No jugglers box, I'll assure thee friend: for here's neither pass, nor repass, I stand here you see for an example, and could wish all these good people to follow it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who's that, Bootes mounted in his Charles wain? doth he cry pippings, carrots, or turnips?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: You are deceived, signior: rather bread, and meat, as piecrust, bones, and fragments out of the Ludgate man's basket: nay, hold your hands, I beseech you gentlemen, and use your tongues and spare not.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Well, he stands hear but for a show, and I am sure I suffered for it really and indeed.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Bear witness my masters, that is the main malefactor indeed, and I stand here for a show: I'll go no further than his own confession.

sp.speaker: Country fellow
sp.p: They talk of cheaters, here is a twenty shillings piece that I put into my mouth, let any cheater in Christendom cozen me of this, and carry it away cleanly, and I'll not only forgive him, but hug him and embrace him for it, and say he is a very hocus-pocus indeed.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: What said that fellow?

sp.speaker: Pusse.
sp.l: He saith he hath a piece in his mouth, that all Europe shall not cheat him of.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I have marked him, 'tis mine own: and notwithstanding all this melancholy we'll spend it at night in wine and music.

sp.speaker: Count. fellow
sp.p: He that can pluck this piece out of my jaws, spite of my teeth, and I keep my mouth fast shut, I'll say he is more than a cheater, and a doctor Faustus, or Mephistopheles at least.

sp.speaker: Puss.
sp.l: Dost hear how he brags?

sp.speaker: Jullio.
sp.l: 'Tis mine own I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: 1 count.
sp.l: But what's become of my horse?

sp.speaker: 2 count.
sp.l: And what's become of my load of hay?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: May I eat hay with your horse, if they were not both done neatly and cleanly. But gentlemen, and the rest, you see I am at this present your pitiful spectacle. I looked once within this twelvemonth , not to have been mounted in such state: but no man knows what preferment he is born to. You see I have hitherto sailed through this great storm without soiling my suit, spoiling my ruff, or spattering my beaver: thanks to these kind spectators.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: But master fast and loose; do you remember what a slippery trick you served master doctor and us?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: And was it not fairly done master sergeant, to teach you how to digest the wearing of a surplice, before you came to stand in a white sheet.

sp.speaker: 1 sergeant
sp.l: Well now you are at your journey's end: may it please you to alight for your ease?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Withal my heart: and if either you or any of my accusers be weary with following me on foot, the room is now empty, I will give him leave to ride in my place. He seems to fall into a passion.yet when I do but think of this disaster, it draws tears from mine eyes.
sp.l: He draws his handkerchief (As to wipe his eyes) just before the country fellow, and scatters some small money.

sp.speaker: Country fellow.
sp.l: Sir, you have (I think) let fall some money.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Thanks honest friend.

sp.speaker: Count. fellow
sp.l: What do you look for? I can assure you here is all that fell.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l:
Nay, sure I had more money? 'tis not in my handkerchief,
nor in my pockets, I have examined them both.

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.l: Why, what do you want sir?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: A piece, a piece, and had it now, just now; sure whilst I was so high perched none could dive so low into my pocket, it was sure as I lighted, and dropped from me, just as I drew my handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Puss.
sp.l: Some such thing I saw fall.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Pray who were they that stooped?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.l: I saw none stoop but this country fellow.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Then sir, I must demand this piece of you.

sp.speaker: Count. fellow.
sp.l: Of me? I profess I took up but two shillings and six pence, and that I gave into your hand.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: But I profess that one of them was a piece, and never came into my hand, and that I must demand of you: say did nobody stoop but he?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.l: None I assure you.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Thou art still my honest sergeant.

sp.speaker: Puss.
sp.l: That fellow hath something in his mouth.

sp.speaker: Count. fellow
sp.l: Yes my tongue and my teeth, and what of all that.

sp.speaker: Puss.
sp.l: Nay, something else sure, for he is not troubled with the Mumps, and yet see how one side of his cheeks bumps out.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: I am afraid, we shall find him a cheater.

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.l: Sirrah know I am an officer, I charge you open your mouth, and let us see what you have in it, etc.

sp.speaker: Count. fellow
sp.l: Well sir, I have a twenty shillings piece, what then?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.l: And this man misseth a twenty shilling piece out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Plead well sergeant and thou shalt have thy fee.

sp.speaker: Count. fellow
sp.l: Well, there it is, what can you make of it?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Marry twenty shillings good and lawful currant money, puss, was not this the piece that I put in my pocket this morning?

sp.speaker: Puss.
sp.l: I know it by that mark.

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.l: And she's witness sufficient in conscience.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Do you see gentlemen. I am here brought to public penance for a cheater, and here's a plain fellow that (It seems) in his simplicity would outdo me: if I be thus censured merely for suspicion; shall he scape free that is taken in the very action?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: No, no, mount him, mount him.

sp.speaker: Count. fellow
sp.p: Nay, by your favour gentlemen, I have driven a cart often for my pleasure, and would be loath to ride in one now for my punishment. It is penance enough for me to part with my piece, which cannot be more currant of coin, then his is arrant for knavery.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: He's gone, I am still here, now gentlemen,
If heretofore there hath been any doll,
Any bold Beachum, and any cutpurse Moll.
Any bawd fat with wealth, or with care meager,
That spends her time in garrison or leaguer,
Grace me so far to say, that of a cheater
Though some have been more grave; scarce any greater,
But gentlemen; what need we more repeating?
Knowing, that even in all trades there is cheating?
'Tis common both in buying and in selling,
In all commerce; nay, even in money telling.
'Tis frequent 'twixt the pander and the whore,
We ourselves find it at the playhouse door.
And though (For an example) here I stand,
I am not all the cheaters in the land.
Some here (No question) know it but I vow,
(They what they please) I will cheat none of you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We understand their humours,
And the cause of their distempers;
And have too long suffered such weeds
As these to flourish in our soil,
But now no longer shall this earth of ours,
Like a kind mother lend her fruits increase,
To cherish those would eclipse her worth.
But those whose aims and acts are imitable,
Crown with green garlands, and with bowls brimmed full.
Music proclaim a general festival,
A jubilee of joy and mirth to all:
May love and truth, never like comfort miss,
Nor knave in grain, scape a reward like this.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
